item.title: 15 years of 26/11: How Mumbai terror attacks changed India’s security infrastructure
item.description:
The article discusses the impact of the 26/11 attacks in Mumbai on India's security concerns and the measures taken by the Indian government in response. The attacks exposed vulnerabilities in India's maritime and internal security, as well as its counter-terrorism infrastructure and local police. To address these issues, the government tightened maritime security, fixed loopholes in the intelligence grid, strengthened the legal framework against terrorism, and created special agencies to investigate terror cases.
The Indian navy was given charge of maritime security, while the Indian Coast Guard took responsibility for territorial waters and coordinated with new marine police stations along the coastline. It became mandatory for vessels longer than 20 meters to have an Automatic Identification System (AIS) for transmitting identification and other information. The Intelligence Bureau's Multi Agency Centre (MAC) was also strengthened to enhance intelligence exchange and coordination among central agencies, armed forces, and state police.
The article highlights that the definition of terrorism was expanded under the Unlawful Activities Prevention Act (UAPA), and the National Investigation Agency (NIA) Act was passed to establish a federal investigation agency. These changes were driven by public opinion and the pressure to address terrorism effectively. However, the proposed National Counter Terrorism Centre could not be implemented due to concerns about violating the existing federal structure of policing.
The focus on modernization of state police forces and allocation of more funds aimed to equip them with advanced technology, training, and better weapons. Crack commando teams were established within police forces, and four regional hubs of the National Security Guard (NSG) were set up across the country.
The 26/11 attacks also led to increased cooperation between the West and India on security matters. The US provided real-time information and prosecutable evidence during the attacks, including the arrest of David Coleman Headley, who conducted reconnaissance for the attacks. This cooperation helped expose Pakistan's involvement and isolate it internationally. India gained support from Saudi Arabia, Persian Gulf countries, and China in countering groups like Lashkar-e-Tayyeba (LeT).
However, the article highlights remaining gaps in India's security grid, with state police forces still ill-equipped, poorly trained, and subject to political interference. There are also challenges in tracking ships that do not transmit AIS signals, particularly smaller fishing vessels without transponders.
Overall, the 26/11 attacks prompted significant changes and improvements in India's security apparatus, but there is still work to be done to address the remaining vulnerabilities.

item.title: China pneumonia outbreak: Here’s everything we know
item.description: China is experiencing a surge in respiratory illnesses as it enters its first full winter season after lifting Covid-19 restrictions. The spike in reported cases of respiratory illnesses has resulted in a high number of hospitalizations, particularly in Beijing and Liaoning. Children are the most affected group, while the elderly and pregnant women may also be vulnerable. Chinese authorities attribute the increase in cases to known pathogens such as influenza, mycoplasma pneumoniae, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), and SARS-CoV-2. This outbreak is not considered a new disease like Covid-19. Experts believe the lifting of Covid-19 restrictions and the onset of winter are contributing factors. Authorities have urged the public to take precautionary measures, although people in China seem relatively calm about the situation. Chinese authorities expect the influenza peak to continue throughout the winter and spring, with mycoplasma pneumoniae remaining a concern. Although the outbreak is currently contained, vigilance is necessary, and vaccines and medicines are likely to be available if needed. It is emphasized that the world is better equipped now to handle infectious diseases due to the experience gained from the global pandemic.

item.title: Does the Indian judiciary have a ‘patriarchy problem’?
item.description:
Justice Fathima Beevi, the first Indian woman to become a Supreme Court judge, has passed away at the age of 96. She was appointed to the Supreme Court in 1989, becoming the first Muslim woman judge of the Supreme Court and the first woman Supreme Court Justice in Asia. Despite acknowledging the patriarchal nature of the judiciary, she believed that her appointment paved the way for other women.
Since 1989, only 10 women have been appointed as Supreme Court judges. Currently, out of the 33 Supreme Court judges, only three are female. However, in 2021, the appointments of Justices Hima Kohli, Bela Trivedi, and BV Nagarathna made history by having four female judges serving simultaneously, the highest number so far. In total, there have been only 11 women judges out of the 268 judges in the Supreme Court's history, accounting for just 4.1% of all judges.
The situation in High Courts is not much better. Out of 1,114 sanctioned judges, only 782 are currently working, and among them, only 107 judges are female, constituting only 13% of the total. None of the country's 25 High Courts have a female Chief Justice, except for the Gujarat High Court, where Justice Sunita Agarwal was appointed due to the absence of any female Chief Justices.
The representation of women in the lower judiciary is relatively higher at 27%. However, there is still a glass ceiling when it comes to higher appointments such as district judges and high court judges. A study found that the percentage of women judges in the lower judiciary remains below 40%, except for a few states that have implemented quotas for women.
The lack of female representation in the judiciary can be attributed to factors such as an entrenched "old boys' club mentality," sexual harassment, lack of trust from clients, and inadequate supportive infrastructure. The lower judiciary has better representation compared to the High Court and Supreme Court, possibly because entry is through an examination rather than informal channels used in higher courts.
Despite efforts to improve gender diversity, there are still challenges in appointing more women judges. Some women advocates have declined offers due to domestic responsibilities, while others argue that men who refuse judgeship due to financial reasons have not hindered the collegium from appointing more male judges.

item.title: How gene therapy will revolutionise treatment of sickle cell disease
item.description:
The UK drug regulator has approved a groundbreaking gene therapy called Casgevy for the treatment of sickle cell disease and thalassaemia. This therapy, based on the Nobel Prize-winning gene editing technology Crispr-Cas9, is the first licensed therapy of its kind in the world. Casgevy works by editing the faulty gene responsible for these blood disorders, potentially providing a lifelong cure. Previously, the only permanent treatment option was a bone marrow transplant, which required finding a closely matched donor.
Both sickle cell disease and thalassaemia are caused by errors in the gene for haemoglobin, a protein that carries oxygen in red blood cells. Casgevy uses the patient's own blood stem cells and targets a gene called BCL11A, crucial for the switch from foetal to adult haemoglobin. By increasing the production of foetal haemoglobin, which lacks the abnormalities found in adult haemoglobin, Casgevy alleviates the symptoms of these conditions.
Sickle cell disease causes red blood cells to take on a crescent shape, hampering their movement through blood vessels and leading to blocked blood flow, severe pain, infections, anaemia, and strokes. In India alone, an estimated 30,000-40,000 children are born with this disorder annually. Thalassaemia, on the other hand, results in low levels of haemoglobin, causing fatigue, shortness of breath, irregular heartbeats, and the need for lifelong blood transfusions.
In clinical trials, Casgevy showed promising results. For sickle cell disease, 29 out of 45 patients experienced no severe pain crises for at least 12 months after treatment. In thalassaemia, 39 out of 42 patients did not require transfusion for the same duration, while the need for transfusion decreased by 70% in the remaining three patients.
Administering Casgevy involves collecting blood stem cells through apheresis, editing and testing them over a six-month period, and then performing a transplant to replace the patient's bone marrow. The patient typically stays in the hospital for at least a month to ensure successful integration of the edited cells.
Although the price of Casgevy has not been disclosed, it is expected to be high, possibly reaching $2 million per patient. This cost, along with the absence of local manufacturing facilities, poses challenges to widespread access, particularly in poorer countries. However, experts believe that as more research is conducted and local manufacturing becomes available, the prices of gene therapies are likely to decrease.
Overall, the approval of Casgevy represents a significant milestone in gene therapy, offering hope for patients with sickle cell disease and thalassaemia.

item.title: ‘Hell on Earth’: What is the humanitarian situation in Gaza?
item.description: A four-day humanitarian pause in the conflict in Gaza has begun, providing an opportunity for aid agencies to increase deliveries to the besieged enclave. Food, fuel, drinking water, and medicine shortages have worsened in recent weeks, leading United Nations agencies to warn of potential mass disease outbreaks. Over 1.7 million people out of Gaza's population of 2.3 million are estimated to be internally displaced. Shelters run by the UN Palestinian refugee agency are overcrowded, with many civilians seeking refuge from Israeli bombardments. Hospitals in northern Gaza are not functioning normally due to ongoing attacks and fuel shortages. Only eight out of eleven facilities in the south remain operational, and only one can perform complex surgeries. The World Health Organization has reported a significant rise in premature births due to stress and trauma among pregnant mothers. While some aid supplies have entered through the Rafah crossing, all other crossings into Gaza remain closed. Fresh fuel deliveries have allowed some water wells and pumping stations in the south to resume operations, but the north is facing dehydration concerns as the water desalination plant and Israeli pipeline supplying water are not functional. Wastewater treatment plants are also not operating at full capacity, leading to sewage overflow in certain areas. Israel has allowed a limited amount of fuel to enter Gaza from Egypt, which is being distributed by the UNRWA to support critical services such as food distribution, hospitals, and sanitation facilities.

item.title: OpenAI saga: Sam Altman’s firing, return, and future
item.description:
Sam Altman has been reinstated as the CEO of OpenAI after a five-day period of turmoil at the company. Altman was initially ousted by the board of directors, but an agreement between him and the company led to his return. The incident highlighted the ongoing debate about the deployment of AI and could signify a shift in OpenAI's focus towards rapid commercialization, potentially giving more influence to investors like Microsoft.
Altman's dismissal came after accusations of lack of transparency with the board. Greg Brockman, the president and co-founder, also lost his board seat and subsequently resigned in solidarity. This led to an uproar among OpenAI employees, with almost all 800 signing an open letter threatening to quit and follow Altman to Microsoft unless the board members who dismissed him were removed.
OpenAI later announced Altman's return and a reshuffling of the board. Three board members were removed, leaving only one holdover. Two new members were added, and the board might expand further. The ousting of Altman stemmed from a growing rift between him and other board members, including concerns about the potential risks of OpenAI's technology to society.
One specific issue involved Altman's disagreement with Helen Toner over her research paper that compared OpenAI's safety approach with rival company Anthropic. Altman tried to push out Toner but ended up being ousted himself when other board members joined forces against him. The board members also failed to agree on candidates to fill vacant seats, adding to the internal tensions.
The reshuffling of the board suggests a shift towards maximizing the commercial potential of AI at OpenAI. New board members may be more aligned with Altman's ambitions in this regard. OpenAI is expected to focus on developing its most powerful model, GPT-5, and face increasing competition from companies like Google, Amazon, Meta, and Anthropic. However, experts express concerns about the release of AI products without full understanding of their behavior, uses, and misuses, which could necessitate stricter regulation.
The safety concerns surrounding AI may prompt politicians to take regulatory measures. In the US, President Joe Biden recently signed an executive order requiring leading AI developers to share safety test results and other information with the government.

item.title: Streaming HD videos from space? Why a NASA spacecraft fired a laser at Earth
item.description: NASA's Psyche spacecraft, en route to a metal-rich asteroid between Mars and Jupiter, has successfully fired a laser signal back to Earth. This asteroid is believed to be the core of an early planet, providing insight into our own planet's iron core. Additionally, the spacecraft is testing a revolutionary technology called Deep Space Optical Communications (DSOC), which uses near-infrared laser signals for communication. This technology allows for data rates at least 10 times higher than current radio systems, enabling higher resolution images and streaming video. DSOC requires extremely precise pointing and compensates for the changing positions of Earth and the spacecraft. The successful implementation of DSOC could revolutionize communication in deep space, paving the way for future space exploration missions.

item.title: Here’s what we know about the Israel-Hamas deal
item.description: A temporary cease-fire agreement is expected to take effect between Israel and Hamas, mediated in part by Qatar. The deal involves a four-day pause in hostilities and an exchange of hostages and prisoners. Approximately 50 women and children abducted by Israeli officials on October 7 will be exchanged for 150 Palestinian women and minors imprisoned in Israeli jails. The specifics of the increased humanitarian aid from Qatar are unknown. During the pause, Israeli warplanes will not fly over southern Gaza, and there will be a six-hour daily restriction on flying over the northern part of the territory. The cease-fire is scheduled to start at 7 a.m. Gaza time on Friday, with the release of 13 hostages at 4 p.m. Each day, Israel and Hamas will exchange lists of hostages and prisoners through Qatar, with the International Committee of the Red Cross designated to receive the hostages. The hostages released by Hamas will be taken to hospitals, and their families will meet them there. Palestinian prisoners released from Israeli prisons will be transported by bus to their home districts. The Israeli government published a list of 300 names of Palestinians being considered for release, all of whom are described as "security prisoners." The list includes 32 women and girls, along with boys aged 14 to 18. It is unclear who among them will be released. Additionally, three Americans (two women and a toddler) are also expected to be released.

item.title: How farm fires are counted, why the data has some limitations
item.description: The farm fire season in the national capital is coming to an end, sparking debates about its contribution to pollution levels. Between September 15 and November 23, a total of 55,725 farm fires were recorded across six states in India. Punjab had the highest number of fires, with 36,323 recorded, including a single-day count of 3,230 on November 5. The Indian Agricultural Research Institute's (IARI) Consortium for Research on Agroecosystem Monitoring and Modeling from Space (CREAMS) Laboratory collects data on paddy residue fires. They use three NASA satellites equipped with sensors to record land surface temperatures and identify paddy crop residue fires. The data is then processed and shared with various government agencies to help them take appropriate measures. However, limitations include the number of satellites available and weather conditions affecting data collection.

item.title: How the Gulf is planning for a life after oil
item.description: Gulf countries like Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates are embracing renewable energy and building large-scale renewable power plants to meet their emissions targets. This shift is driven not only by environmental concerns but also by the desire to maximize profits by freeing up fossil fuel reserves for export. The region's dependence on oil revenues poses a dilemma since burning fossil fuels contributes to climate change, which disproportionately affects the Gulf. To address this, the region is exploring carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology, although its efficacy remains limited, with less than 0.1% of global emissions currently being captured. The annual UN climate summit, to be held in the UAE, will discuss CCS extensively. However, some nations, including the European Union, oppose focusing on abatement technologies and instead advocate for phasing out fossil fuels. Aware that reduced demand for oil may deplete their coffers in 15 years, Gulf countries are seeking alternative revenue streams. Saudi Arabia and the UAE are investing in green hydrogen production and renewable-powered commodity industries. Exporting solar power is also seen as an economic opportunity. Some states, like Oman, have ambitious plans to reduce reliance on fossil fuels by diversifying their economies through tourism, logistics, and manufacturing. Overall, the Gulf's transition to renewables relies on leveraging fossil fuel reserves to fund the shift, a paradox noted by environmentalists and human rights activists.

item.title: What far right Islamophobe Geert Wilders’ surprise election success means for the Netherlands — and the rest of Europe
item.description:
Geert Wilders, the leader of the Party for Freedom (PVV) in the Netherlands, has emerged as a strong contender to become the next prime minister. In the recent general elections, PVV secured 37 seats, making it the largest party in the 150-seat Dutch parliament. Wilders' success has surprised many and sent shockwaves across Europe, where far-right populist movements have been gaining momentum.
Wilders is known for his anti-immigration, anti-Islam, and anti-European Union stance. He has been a career politician since 1998 and founded PVV in 2006 after leaving the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD). His controversial views on immigration from Muslim countries and his opposition to Islam have drawn attention both nationally and internationally.
The election campaign was largely centered around the issue of restricting asylum-seekers, which resonated with Wilders' message. He called for a halt to accepting asylum-seekers and advocated for stricter border control. Additionally, he has criticized the European Union and supported the idea of a Brexit-like referendum in the Netherlands.
Despite his hardline positions, Wilders has recently attempted to soften his rhetoric on Islam to appeal to potential coalition partners. The formation of a government requires the support of at least 76 MPs, and some parties have already ruled out working with Wilders. Coalition talks are ongoing, but incumbent Prime Minister Mark Rutte is expected to remain as caretaker PM until a government is formed.
Wilders' victory reflects the broader trend of populist and far-right parties gaining traction in European elections. Leaders such as Hungary's Viktor Orban and France's Marine Le Pen have praised Wilders' success, highlighting the growing discontent with the current state of the European Union and immigration policies.
As the Netherlands is often considered a bellwether for Europe, Wilders' rise to power raises questions about the future direction of the continent and its response to immigration and EU integration.

item.title: 25 years of the International Space Station: Why it was launched, what it does
item.description:
The International Space Station (ISS) orbits the Earth 16 times a day and is often overlooked despite its scientific significance. It has been a hub for international collaboration and diplomacy for the past 25 years. The ISS was established with the launch of the Russian Zarya Control Module in November 1998, followed by the US Unity Node 1 module a month later. It has undergone 42 assembly flights to become what it is today and has been continuously inhabited since its inception.
The ISS consists of various living and working areas, including sleeping quarters, bathrooms, a gym, and a bay window with a 360-degree view. Its dimensions are impressive, measuring 109 meters end-to-end, comparable to an American football field or more than twice the length of an Olympic swimming pool. The solar array wingspan matches its overall length, while approximately 13 kilometers of electrical wires run through the station.
In addition to conducting scientific experiments that cannot be done on Earth, astronauts on the ISS perform regular spacewalks to install new components and conduct maintenance. They also follow a strict health regimen to counteract the negative impacts of microgravity, such as muscle and bone loss. Understanding how humans adapt to long-term space habitation is crucial, especially for future missions to the moon or Mars.
Numerous scientific experiments have been conducted on the ISS, some focusing on the astronauts themselves and others benefiting researchers on Earth. These experiments have led to breakthroughs in various fields, including Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, cancer, asthma, heart disease, drug development, water purification, and food production.
However, the future of the ISS became uncertain due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Several countries, including Russia itself, expressed intentions to develop their own independent space stations. Despite this, the US and Europe remain committed to the ISS until 2030, while NASA focuses on the Artemis program for lunar exploration, and the European Space Agency (ESA) works towards building a new space station called Starlab.
The future of space exploration continues to evolve, with various nations striving to make independent strides in this domain. The phrase "watch this space" takes on new significance as plans for the post-ISS era unfold.

item.title: What is the new Investor Risk Reduction Access platform, and how it stands to benefit investors
item.description:
The Investor Risk Reduction Access (IRRA) platform has been launched by the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) to provide a safety net for investors in case of technical glitches faced by trading members or stock brokers registered with SEBI. Developed jointly by all the major stock exchanges in India, including BSE, NSE, NCDEX, MCX, and MSE, the platform allows investors to close open positions and cancel pending orders in the event of disruption at the stock brokers' end.
The purpose of IRRA is to reduce risks for investors during technical glitches or unforeseen outages that make the trading member's site inaccessible. It offers investors the opportunity to square off/close their open positions and cancel pending orders using the platform. However, it is important to note that IRRA is not intended for taking fresh positions or orders; its sole function is to cancel pending orders.
The need for IRRA arose due to increasing reliance on technology in the securities market, which has led to an increase in trading system glitches and disruptions. In such instances, investors with open positions are at risk of not being able to close their positions if the markets are volatile and the trading member's systems are affected. To address this issue, SEBI announced the provision of a contingency service by stock exchanges in the event of such disruptions.
The IRRA platform can be invoked by trading members when they face technical glitches impacting their ability to serve clients across exchanges. It enables investors to view and cancel pending orders, close open positions, and cancel orders across segments and exchanges. The platform can be accessed through a secure login system using a Unique Client Code (UCC) or investor's PAN number, along with a one-time password (OTP) sent to their registered mobile numbers and email IDs for authorization.
To migrate to the IRRA platform, trading members need to restore their primary and disaster recovery sites before requesting the stock exchanges. Once the issue is fixed and sufficient testing is performed, the trading member can inform the exchanges to resume business from the original trading system. Reverse migration from IRRA to the trading member is only allowed once during a trading day.
Overall, the IRRA platform aims to provide a safety net for investors in case of technical glitches or disruptions faced by trading members, allowing them to manage their positions effectively and reduce potential risks.

item.title: A political history of Rajasthan: A Congress-BJP revolving door
item.description:
Rajasthan, the largest state in India, has a history of stable governments with only three Chief Ministers in the last 33 years. The state has never witnessed a government collapse and power has consistently alternated between the Congress and the BJP since 1993. The state legislature consists of 200 seats, with reserved seats for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. Assembly elections have often resulted in a near majority for one party, but the largest party has always managed to form a government by gathering support from other parties.
The Congress and BJP are the dominant parties in Rajasthan, with no other party ruling the state. However, there have been occasional emerging political forces that eventually merged with either Congress or BJP. Over the years, both parties have had significant victories in different elections, with the BJP's best performance being in 2013 when they won 163 out of 200 seats.
The state has witnessed the dismissal of elected governments three times by the central government. In 1977, the Morarji Desai government dismissed the Congress government in Rajasthan. The Chief Minister, Bhairon Singh Shekhawat, was also sacked twice - once in 1980 by Indira Gandhi and again in 1992 by P V Narasimha Rao after the demolition of the Babri Masjid.
The political landscape in Rajasthan has seen influential leaders from various parties, including L K Advani, Sundar Singh Bhandari, Satish Agarwal, Jaswant Singh, and Ramdas Agrawal. While the state has occasionally seen the rise of third political forces, they have usually disappeared or merged with one of the major parties.
Elections in Rajasthan primarily revolve around the Congress and the BJP, with Ashok Gehlot and Vasundhara Raje as their respective prominent faces. Gehlot, an OBC Mali, has been a strong leader for the Congress, while Vasundhara Raje, who assumed office in 2003, remains the prominent leader for the BJP in the state. However, she has been sidelined in recent years.
The longest-serving Chief Minister in Rajasthan has been Sukhadia of the Congress, followed by Gehlot, Shekhawat, and Vasundhara. The state has seen leaders from various communities, including Brahmins, Vaishyas, Kayasthas, Muslims, and Rajputs, but no Jat or ST leader has become Chief Minister yet.
Overall, Rajasthan has a history of stable governments with power alternating between the Congress and the BJP. Despite occasional challenges and dismissals, the largest party has always managed to form a government by gathering support from other parties.

item.title: Gujarat gets a state fish: Why ghol, the ‘fisherman’s lottery’, was chosen
item.description: The black-spotted croaker, also known as the ghol fish, has been declared the state fish of Gujarat. The decision was made by the government based on its economic value and uniqueness. The ghol fish is predominantly found in the Indo-Pacific region, stretching from the Persian Gulf to the Pacific Ocean. By declaring it the state fish, Gujarat aims to contribute to its conservation efforts. The selection process involved consultations with representatives from all districts, considering other species like ribbon fish, pomfret, and Bombay Duck. While the local consumption of ghol fish is not widespread, it has a significant market in China and other countries. It is considered a delicacy in many places and is used for medicinal purposes in others. The meat of the fish is exported to European and Middle-Eastern countries, while the dried air bladder is in high demand in Asian countries. A kilogram of ghol fish can fetch substantial prices, with the dried air bladder being the costliest. Gujarat's total fish production in 2021-22 was estimated at 8.74 lakh tons, worth Rs 11,221 crore, of which 2.3 lakh tons were exported, valued at Rs 5,233 crore.

item.title: Who is Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, the alleged target of a planned hit job in the US?
item.description:
The article reports that the United States government uncovered a plot to assassinate Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, the leader of the Khalistani separatist organization Sikhs for Justice (SFJ), on American soil. The US government also issued a warning to the Indian government regarding their potential involvement in the conspiracy. It is unclear whether the US protest prompted the plotters to abandon their plan or if the FBI intervened to foil an already underway scheme. US federal prosecutors have filed a sealed indictment against at least one perpetrator in a New York district court.
Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, in his mid to late 40s, hails from Khankot village near Amritsar and is an attorney in the US. He is known as the founder and leader of SFJ, which aims to achieve self-determination for Sikhs in the Indian-held Punjab region and establish a sovereign state called Khalistan. Pannun advocates for a peaceful approach, with the motto "ballots not bullets," but has been criticized for his ties to terrorists and controversial activities.
The SFJ gained attention through its "Referendum 2020" campaign among the Sikh diaspora worldwide, claiming significant support. However, skeptics question the legitimacy of the referendum due to the lack of reliable rules and verification processes. Despite limited traction for the Khalistan movement in Punjab and the Sikh diaspora, Pannun and SFJ remain in the news through periodic statements against the Indian state and in support of Khalistan.
The Indian government views Pannun and SFJ as secessionist and militant entities operating from foreign safe havens. Multiple cases, including sedition charges, have been registered against Pannun and SFJ in India. In January 2021, during the farmers' agitation, the National Investigation Agency (NIA) initiated an investigation into their funding sources. Pannun has been labeled a "terrorist" by the Indian government and has faced legal action under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act. The Home Ministry issued a notification banning SFJ, accusing them of promoting secessionism and militant ideology in Punjab with support from foreign forces.

item.title: Vir Das wins: What are the Emmy Awards and their different types?
item.description:
Comedian Vir Das has become the first Indian to win an International Emmy Award in the comedy category for his Netflix show, "Vir Das: Landing on Monday." He shared the award with the British series "Derry Girls" season 3. Additionally, Ekta Kapoor, a producer, filmmaker, and co-founder of Balaji Telefilms, was honored with this year's Directorate Award for her outstanding contributions to international television.
The International Emmy Awards differ from the Primetime Emmy Awards, which are considered one of the most prestigious award events in television. The article provides an overview of the various types of Emmy Awards, their history, and the organizations responsible for presenting them.
The Emmy Awards were established in 1948, with the first ceremony taking place in 1949. Initially, six awards were presented, including categories such as Most Outstanding Television Personality and Most Popular Television Program.
In addition to the International Emmy Awards and Primetime Emmy Awards, the Emmys are also given in other categories, such as daytime, sports, news and documentary, technology and engineering, and regional awards. Each category is overseen by a different organization: the Television Academy administers the Primetime Emmy Awards, the National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences oversees daytime, sports, news and documentary categories, and the International Academy of Television Arts & Sciences is responsible for International Emmys.
The article explains that the word "Emmy" doesn't stand for anything specific and was chosen because it was more "feminine." Initially, the award was planned to be named "Immy," derived from the image-orthicon camera tube used in television technology. However, it was decided to change the name to "Emmy" as the statuette depicts a winged muse representing art uplifting the electron of science.
Overall, the Emmy Awards are highly esteemed honors for television and emerging media performances, recognizing excellence in various categories and promoting both American and international shows.

item.title: Humanitarian pause in Gaza: How it is not the same as a ceasefire
item.description: Qatar has announced a four-day humanitarian pause between Israel and Hamas, facilitated by Qatar, Egypt, and the United States. The pause aims to provide relief to war-torn Gaza but is not a ceasefire. A humanitarian pause is a temporary cessation of hostilities for humanitarian purposes, limited to a specific area and time period. The exact geography is unspecified, but the pause will allow the release of hostages held in Gaza and the entry of humanitarian aid convoys. In contrast, a ceasefire is a longer-term agreement to stop fighting and engage in dialogue for a political settlement. Israel opposes a ceasefire as it believes it would benefit Hamas. The humanitarian pause offers some relief but allows Israel to continue its military assault. Critics argue that it is insufficient and prolongs the suffering. Advocates of a ceasefire call for lifting the siege on Gaza and genuine negotiations for an independent Palestinian state.

item.title: Have we lost the fight against climate change
item.description:
The article discusses the current state of the fight against climate change and highlights several concerning findings. It notes that global temperatures on November 17 exceeded the pre-industrial baseline by more than 2 degrees Celsius for the first time, indicating a significant spike in global warming. The article emphasizes that efforts to combat climate change have been largely ineffective, leading to an increase in weather-related disasters. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) states that global greenhouse gas emissions need to be reduced by at least 43% from 2019 levels by 2030 to limit the rise in global temperatures within 1.5 degrees Celsius from pre-industrial levels.
However, the latest Emissions Gap Report reveals that emissions are actually increasing. In 2022, global emissions were over a billion tonnes higher than in 2019, with only a decline observed in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Meeting the 2030 target would require an average annual reduction of almost 9%, which is deemed nearly impossible. Current climate actions are projected to result in just a 2% reduction in emissions by 2030, far below the necessary level.
As temperatures continue to rise, countries must adapt to a warmer environment and deal with the consequences of climate change. Developing countries, entitled to financial assistance under the Paris Agreement, expected support from wealthier nations. However, the availability of adaptation funds has declined by almost 15% while the combined requirements of developing countries amount to at least US$215 billion annually, more than ten times the current funding.
The article also mentions the importance of addressing "Loss and Damage," referring to the financial assistance needed by countries affected by climate disasters. Although a fund was established for this purpose, it currently lacks sufficient resources. The fight against climate change relies heavily on developed countries taking the lead, both in reducing emissions and providing financial support. However, the promise of US$100 billion annually made by developed countries in 2009 appears outdated and insufficient considering the current requirements.
The article concludes that meeting emission reduction targets by 2030, aligned with global climate goals, seems highly unlikely. Daily temperatures have already exceeded pre-industrial averages on numerous occasions this year, and 2023 is projected to be the warmest year ever recorded. While technological interventions like carbon dioxide removal may offer some solutions, they are not yet mainstream or economically viable. Crossing the 1.5 degree Celsius threshold would bring challenges, such as disruptions, loss of livelihoods, and increased vulnerability for marginalized populations, although notions of human extinction or the end of life on the planet may be exaggerated.

item.title: The case from Netflix’s ‘Take Care of Maya’, and the $261 million awarded in damages over it
item.description: A jury in Florida has awarded $261 million in damages to a family who accused Johns Hopkins Hospital of false imprisonment, battery, and medical negligence. The charges stem from allegations that the hospital prevented the family from seeing their daughter while she was admitted there. The case gained further attention when the daughter, now 17 years old, leveled additional charges of assault and sexual abuse against the hospital, leading to a criminal complaint. The family's separation from their daughter, which lasted several months, is believed to have contributed to the mother's suicide in 2017. The family's story was featured in a Netflix documentary called "Take Care of Maya." The article also provides background on the initial symptoms the daughter experienced, her treatment with ketamine, and the hospital's response. A child abuse expert concluded that the child's illness was being fabricated, leading to a shelter order that separated the child from her parents. After the mother's death, the daughter was allowed to return home, and the family sued both the hospital and a child welfare service company. The article highlights the lack of oversight on such actors and Florida's aggressive approach to identifying child abuse.

item.title: How the Dutch election may buck Europe’s populist trend
item.description: The upcoming Dutch election is causing uncertainty among voters in Tilburg, with many still undecided. The election will bring a new premier as Mark Rutte steps down after serving as prime minister since 2010. The three leading parties are polling closely, allowing for various coalition possibilities in the Dutch multiparty system. Even experienced voters like Rien Vissers are unsure, torn between a center-left alliance and the Christian democratic party. Pieter Omtzigt, known for exposing a child benefits scandal, has gained attention with his new party, New Social Contract (NSC). Omtzigt's anti-establishment stance and trustworthiness have resonated with voters who see him as an alternative to the status quo. Although not a populist party, NSC represents those dissatisfied with the political establishment. Omtzigt has attracted support from the left, center-right, and far right due to his broad appeal. His prominence has contributed to a calmer tone and greater focus on content in this election season. Despite Omtzigt's success, caution is advised against generalizing it to European politics. As EU elections approach in June 2024, it remains uncertain if Omtzigt's rise can predict broader trends.

item.title: November 21, 1962: Why China called ceasefire in a war it was winning against India
item.description: The article discusses the ceasefire declared by China in its war with India in 1962. China's dominance in the conflict led to territorial gains, capturing Aksai Chin in the west but withdrawing behind the McMahon Line in the east. Experts attribute the war to factors such as India's "Forward Policy" and granting sanctuary to the Dalai Lama. The war ended due to China's stretched supply lines and the potential escalation of international support for India. China's decision to fight back was aimed at striking a peace with its neighbor.

item.title: What is tantalum, the rare metal found in Sutlej?
item.description: Tantalum is a rare metal with the atomic number 73. It is grey, heavy, very hard, and highly corrosion-resistant. When exposed to air, it forms an oxide layer that is difficult to remove. Tantalum is ductile and has a high melting point. It was discovered in 1802 by Anders Gustaf Ekenberg, a Swedish chemist. The metal is named after the Greek mythological figure Tantalus. Tantalum is widely used in electronics and semiconductors due to its high capacitance and small size. It is also used in chemical plants, nuclear power plants, aerospace, and medical equipment. Additionally, a composite of tantalum carbide and graphite is used in high-speed machine tools.

item.title: Which countries recognise Hamas as a ‘terrorist’ organisation?
item.description: Israel has designated Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT) as a terrorist organization, emphasizing its role in the killing of hundreds of Indian civilians. The move coincides with the 15th anniversary of the 26/11 terror attacks in Mumbai and Israel's conflict with Hamas. Israel's Defense and Foreign Affairs ministries collaborated to expedite LeT's listing, highlighting the need for a unified global front against terrorism. This action is seen as a nudge to India to designate Hamas as a terrorist organization, as Israel seeks international support for its campaign in Gaza. Only a few jurisdictions currently designate Hamas as a terrorist group. The article also mentions the six countries and the European Union that consider Hamas a terrorist organization. Designating a group as a terrorist organization involves specific criteria and can lead to various restrictions, such as asset freezes and property takeovers.

item.title: How a NASA experiment will study ‘air glow’ to understand Space weather, why it matters
item.description: NASA is set to launch the Atmospheric Waves Experiment (AWE) to study one of the important drivers of Space weather – the Earth's weather. Space weather, like terrestrial weather, is influenced by solar flares and emissions from the Sun, as well as the prevailing matter in space. Extreme events in Earth's weather can also impact space weather, affecting satellite-based communication, radio communication, and navigation systems. Atmospheric Gravity Waves (AGWs) are vertical waves generated by extreme weather events or disturbances in the atmosphere. AGWs play a role in space weather and their understanding is crucial for improving weather forecasts. AWE, a NASA mission mounted on the International Space Station, will study the interactions between terrestrial and space weather by measuring airglow in the upper atmosphere. It aims to understand the forces that drive space weather and their connection to terrestrial weather. AWE will provide valuable data for weather modeling and enhance our understanding of space weather.

item.title: Uttarakhand tunnel collapse: ‘In building Himalayan tunnels, support and monitoring key’, say experts
item.description:
The collapse of the Silkyara-Barkot tunnel in Uttarkashi, Uttarakhand has raised questions about the support structures and monitoring during the excavation process. Experts emphasize the importance of providing adequate support to weak rock and closely monitoring the tunnel construction. Weak rock masses are common in the Himalayas, and when movement occurs between two rocks, shear zones are created. These zones can contain crushed rock that behaves differently under stress. Measures such as forepoles and rock bolts are taken to protect weak sections, depending on their length and strata. Data collected during construction will be crucial in determining the cause of the collapse.
To investigate the collapse, the Uttarakhand government has formed an expert committee consisting of representatives from various institutions. The committee aims to gather data and understand why the collapse occurred. Identification of weak zones typically occurs during geological mapping before excavation, and appropriate protection measures should be taken. Periodic monitoring is essential due to the possibility of unforeseen geological occurrences. Monitoring can be done using instrumentation and sensors to record any displacement.
Experts highlight the significance of having an escape tunnel in tunnel construction projects. The escape tunnel is excavated simultaneously with the main tunnel and provides valuable information about the geology ahead of the main tunnel. It also serves as a means of emergency exit in case of incidents like fires. Guidelines on safety practices recommend marking specific escape routes in contingency planning.
The presence of the Barkot thrust, a prominent fault, in the area may have contributed to the existence of shear zones in the tunnel. The geology report on the tunnel mentioned that rocks near the Barkot bend are weak to moderately strong and slightly to moderately weathered. Experts suggest that the collapse may have been due to a lack of necessary emergency preparedness and safety measures.

item.title: What Javier Milei’s win in Argentina’s Presidential election means
item.description: Javier Milei, a 53-year-old libertarian and political outsider, has won the national elections in Argentina, securing 56% of the vote. Similar to former US President Donald Trump, Milei tapped into voter anger against the country's political establishment and promised a new political era. This result has been labeled a "protest vote" by experts due to Argentina's history of economic mismanagement and corruption, resulting in high inflation, a depreciating currency, rising poverty, and empty government coffers. The blame is largely placed on the left-leaning Peronists who have dominated Argentine politics since the 1940s. Milei, known as 'El Loco' (The Madman), has advocated for radical economic measures such as abolishing the central bank, reducing government spending, and dollarizing the economy. While this may provide short-term stability, it would relinquish control over monetary policy to Washington decision-makers, which is unprecedented for a country the size of Argentina. Milei is also known for his flamboyant and provocative style, having gained fame as a television personality before entering politics. He is anti-abortion, skeptical of human-driven climate change, supports looser gun laws, and has criticized Pope Francis. Despite his victory, Milei's policies have raised concerns among some voters.

item.title: A brief history of OpenAI — and what led to Sam Altman’s ouster
item.description: Microsoft has hired OpenAI co-founders Sam Altman and Greg Brockman to lead a new advanced AI research team, according to an announcement by Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella. This comes shortly after Altman's sudden ouster from OpenAI, which surprised both employees and investors. OpenAI was established in 2015 as a non-profit organization with the goal of developing artificial general intelligence (AGI) for the benefit of humanity. The organization released a report in 2017 introducing Generative Pre-trained Transformers (GPTs), which gained significant attention. In 2019, OpenAI transitioned into two organizations, one for-profit and one non-profit. Despite establishing a for-profit subsidiary, OpenAI continued to prioritize its mission to control AGI development for the benefit of humanity. OpenAI made headlines with the release of ChatGPT, based on the GPT-3.5 architecture, which garnered significant interest. Tensions among OpenAI's leadership ultimately led to Altman's removal, with the board having the power to decide leadership independently of investors. Following Altman's dismissal, more than 500 OpenAI employees signed an open letter calling for the board's resignation.

item.title: Why have Houthis seized an India-bound ship, how this is linked to the Gaza war
item.description: The Yemen rebel group Houthis has seized an Israel-linked ship bound for India, raising concerns about the ongoing Gaza conflict. The ship, Galaxy Leader, was hijacked by Houthi fighters who took all 25 crew members hostage. The Houthis had previously stated that they would attack Israel-linked ships if Israel continued its actions in Palestine. Israel has claimed that the ship is British-owned and Japanese-operated, calling the hijack "another Iranian act of terrorism." The ship is linked to an Israeli billionaire, and Japan is involved as the ship was operated by a Japanese firm. The Houthis are a rebel group in Yemen backed by Iran, and their support for Palestine stems from their opposition to Israel and the West. Their involvement in the conflict could potentially draw in Iran and escalate the situation.

item.title: ‘UFO’ spotted over Imphal airport: A brief history of the term, and the unending curiosity around it
item.description: Flight operations at Bir Tikendrajit International Airport in Imphal, Manipur were disrupted due to the presence of an Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) hovering above the airport. Two flights were diverted and three departing flights were delayed before operations resumed. The term "UFO" refers to any aerial phenomenon that cannot be easily identified. The US Air Force coined this term in 1952, initially defining it as objects that remain unidentified after investigation. However, it is now used more broadly to describe any unidentifiable object. The US government has shown significant interest in UFOs, with former President Barack Obama acknowledging their existence and footage and records depicting objects in the skies that defy explanation. Project Blue Book, a government initiative from 1952 to 1969, compiled thousands of reports, classifying only a small percentage as unidentified. Despite limited data, recent reports suggest that these sightings often occur near US training and testing grounds. UFOs can have various origins, including birds, balloons, natural atmospheric phenomena, or even foreign adversary systems. The heightened interest in UFOs emerged during the Cold War, when the US was focused on protecting itself from Soviet threats. India has not experienced significant UFO culture, but with the proliferation of televisions and cameras, the number of claims has increased. Indian filmmaker Satyajit Ray depicted aliens in his work, inspiring Hollywood films like Steven Spielberg's E.T. The term "UAP" (Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon) is now being used as a broader and newer alternative to "UFO", aiming to avoid confusion and speculation. NASA has also adopted this term and plans to study UAPs from a scientific perspective. While gaining clarity on these phenomena will require time, better data gathering, and scientific scrutiny, there is a recognition that unexplained aerial phenomena have had an impact on national security, affecting pilots' training and operations.

item.title: Batters and bowlers, but only one all-rounder: Why a great Indian team stumbled in the final
item.description: The article discusses India's performance in the ODI World Cup, where they were considered the best team but lost to Australia in the final. Despite the defeat, the Indian team is recognized as one of the greatest in ODIs. They won 10 games in a row, had exceptional batting with high averages and strike rates, and impressive bowling performances. However, the team had flaws, such as a top-heavy batting lineup and lack of a sixth bowling option. These weaknesses were exploited in the final, where India struggled to accelerate and set a below-par target. The article emphasizes the importance of batting depth for allowing the best batters to play freely without fear of exposing the tail. This conservative approach was not unique to the final, as it was evident throughout the tournament. Overall, the article highlights India's statistical success but also points out the flaws that ultimately cost them in the final match.

item.title: Who is Emmett Shear, the new interim CEO of OpenAI?
item.description: Emmett Shear has been appointed as the interim CEO of OpenAI, following the firing of co-founder and CEO Sam Altman. This sudden change comes as OpenAI is in the midst of closing a new funding round that could value the company at over $86 billion. Speculation initially arose that Altman might return to his position, but it was later announced that he will be joining Microsoft to lead a new AI research team. Shear, known for co-founding Twitch and his association with Y Combinator, confirmed his appointment as the interim CEO. The reasons behind Altman's firing are unclear, but there were disagreements within the company regarding the pace of AI development, its monetization, and safety precautions. Shear expressed his plans for the company, including hiring an investigator, engaging with stakeholders, and reforming the management and leadership team.

item.title: The other oil imports India needs to worry about
item.description: India's edible oil imports have increased by almost 1.5 times and more than doubled in rupee value over the past 10 years. Imports of vegetable oils reached a record 16.5 million tonnes in the year ended October 2023, up from 14 million tonnes in the previous year. However, the value of imports fell due to a crash in global prices. India's edible oil production from domestically grown oilseeds and alternative sources amounted to around 10.3 million tonnes in 2022-23, with imports making up the remaining share. The self-sufficiency ratio has declined over the years, and if production is not boosted, annual imports could exceed 20 million tonnes. The two largest contributors to India's edible oil production are mustard and soybean, followed by cottonseed and rice bran. Other oils, such as coconut, sesame, sunflower, and safflower, have seen declines in domestic output. The high import dependence makes both producers and consumers vulnerable to international price fluctuations. Increasing domestic edible oil production would help insulate Indian farmers and households from excess global price volatility. This would require openness to technology, including genetically modified hybrids, and government support for oilseed growers.

item.title: How unbeaten India lost to a plan and some homework
item.description: India's cricket team suffered a defeat to Australia in the World Cup final. Australia's well-executed plan, adaptability to the conditions, and strong fielding contributed to their victory. India had chosen a slow pitch, which ultimately worked against them. Australia's bowlers utilized the pitch by making the ball stop on the batsmen using a variety of deliveries. The fielders also played their part by making accurate throws from the outfield. India's pace attack initially showed promise, but the pitch eased later on, leading to Australia's comfortable win. Australia's victory showcased their ability to perform in big moments and handle pressure.

item.title: This Quote Means: ‘Sport has the power to… unite people in a way little else does’, from Nelson Mandela
item.description: The ICC men's World Cup Final between India and Australia is taking place in Ahmedabad today. Sports, including cricket, have the power to unite people and inspire change, as Nelson Mandela once said. Sports showcase impressive feats and can be linked to regionalism and nationalism. In South Africa, the 1995 Rugby WorldThe ICC Men's World Cup final between India and Australia is taking place in Ahmedabad today. Sports, including cricket, have the power to unite people and inspire change. Nelson Mandela once said that sports can create hope and break down racial barriers. Sports generate awe through impressive feats, and they are often linked to regionalism and nationalism. In South Africa, rugby was seen as a symbol of apartheid, but Mandela's efforts helped change the perception of the rugby team. Despite criticism, Mandela believed in reaching out to bring the diverse groups of the nation together. The team's victory in the 1995 Rugby World Cup final brought common celebrations, but it didn't heal the deep divisions overnight. The underrepresentation of black players in the rugby team highlighted a lack of progress in achieving true reconciliation and economic freedom for all.

item.title: SpaceX loses contact with Starship rocket in new test flight: What happened, significance
item.description: SpaceX's Starship, a spacecraft designed for future moon missions, underwent a repeat test launch in Texas. Unfortunately, the launch did not go as planned, with the second stage experiencing data loss and a rapid unscheduled disassembly of both the super heavy booster and the ship. Despite this setback, SpaceX obtained valuable dataSpaceX's Starship spacecraft, designed to transport astronauts to the moon and beyond, experienced a failed test launch in Texas on Saturday. The launch appeared to be successful initially, but the booster exploded shortly after separating from the ship. The rest of the spacecraft continued on track. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) stated that there were no injuries or property damage and will investigate the incident. SpaceX made several changes following a failed launch in April, including reinforcing the launch pad. The company aims to use Starship for Mars colonization, while NASA plans to return humans to the moon. Both SpaceX and NASA consider such failures part of the development process.

item.title: Why HC has struck down Haryana’s private sector quota, and what happens now
item.description: The Punjab and Haryana High Court has struck down a law passed by the Haryana government in 2020 that provided 75% reservation in private jobs for residents of the state. The court ruled that the law violated fundamental rights outlined in the constitution and deemed it ineffective from the date it came into force. The law required private sector companies to reserve 75% of jobs with a monthly salary of less than Rs 30,000 for residents of Haryana. The Faridabad Industries Association and other Haryana-based associations challenged the law, arguing that it infringed on the constitutional rights of employers and violated the federal structure of India. The Haryana government argued that it had the power to create such reservations under Article 16(4) of the constitution. The court also criticized certain provisions of the law, such as requiring employers to submit reports on local candidates employed and granting immunity to authorized officers. The decision by the high court comes after the Supreme Court set aside an earlier stay on the law and directed the high court to decide its validity within four weeks. Deputy Chief Minister Dushyant Chautala has stated that the Haryana government will move the Supreme Court and file a Special Leave Petition in response to the high court's order.

item.title: Chhath Puja: What is it, what makes it the most important festival of Bihar
item.description: President Droupadi Murmu and Prime Minister Narendra Modi, along with other political leaders, extended their wishes for the Chhath Puja on November 19. This four-day festival is celebrated to honor the sun and involves fasting and making offerings to the rising and setting sun. Chhath Puja has become more visible across the country in recent years, with TV channels broadcasting celebrations taking place even outside of Bihar and eastern Uttar Pradesh. The festival holds great religious significance in Bihar and is deeply rooted in tradition. It is believed to have originated from a time when nature was worshipped, and there are stories from Hindu mythology that associate Lord Ram, Goddess Sita, Draupadi, and Karna with the observance of Chhath. The festival brings together the entire community, with everyone contributing to its success, from cleaning river banks to preparing the ritual food, known as thekuas. Chhath Puja is observed on the sixth day of the Kartik month and sometimes in the month of Chaitra as well. It is a time for devotees to feel a sense of divinity and devotion. The festival is unique in many ways, including the absence of priests and the direct worship of a visible god by devotees. People from all castes can participate, and both men and women observe the fast. The essence of the festival lies in the message that everyone is equal in the eyes of God, and nature deserves reverence.

item.title: Governor’s right to withhold assent: The constitutional question before Supreme Court
item.description:
Tamil Nadu's Governor R N Ravi's decision to withhold assent to 10 pending Bills has sparked legal questions about the powers of the Governor. This issue arises as several opposition-ruled states, including Tamil Nadu, have approached the Supreme Court seeking clarification on the Governor's powers in the lawmaking process. The Tamil Nadu Assembly readopted all the Bills in a special sitting five days after the Governor withheld assent.
The powers of the Governor regarding granting assent to Bills are governed by Articles 163 and 200 of the Constitution. Article 200 specifies that the Governor can grant or withhold assent to a Bill, return it for reconsideration, or reserve it for the President's consideration. However, there is a proviso in Article 200 stating that non-money Bills can be returned for reconsideration, but once they are reconsidered and sent back to the Governor, the Governor must not withhold assent.
Opposition-ruled states have been engaged in a tug-of-war with the Governors due to the ambiguity in the proviso. Raj Bhavans (Governor's residence) have taken advantage of this ambiguity to indefinitely delay Bills without returning them to the state legislature. This indefinite timeline can effectively paralyze the elected government. Nevertheless, giving assent to Bills is an area where the Governor can exercise discretion, but this discretion must be exercised in accordance with the Constitution and based on cogent reasons, rather than personal preference.
The Supreme Court's landmark ruling in the Arunachal Pradesh Assembly case (Nabam Rebia and Bamang Felix vs Deputy Speaker) in 2016 discussed the Governor's role in returning Bills to the Assembly with recommendations for amendments.
Apart from Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Telangana, and Punjab have also sought the Supreme Court's intervention in this matter. Kerala argued that Bills have been pending with the Governor for more than a year or two, while Telangana stated that several key Bills are pending with the Governor for approval since September 2022. Tamil Nadu alleged that the Governor's refusal to sign various orders and Bills is causing a halt in the administration and creating an adversarial attitude by not cooperating with the state government.
Now, the Supreme Court has been called upon to decide whether it can impose a timeline on Governors to give assent to Bills, which would essentially mean determining if it can set limits on an office exercising constitutional powers. In the past, the court has reluctantly set timelines for the Speaker's office to decide disqualification cases. It should be noted that a Governor cannot be directly made a party before the Supreme Court, so notices are issued to the Secretary of the Governor in such disputes.

item.title: Why the Maldives President requested India to withdraw its troops from the island
item.description: Mohamed Muizzu, the newly elected President of Maldives, has formally requested the Indian government to withdraw its military personnel from the country. Muizzu stated that the Maldivian people had given him a strong mandate to make this request, and he hoped that India would honor the democratic will of the Maldivian people. During a meeting with India's Earth Sciences Minister Kiren Rijiju, Muizzu discussed the presence of Indian military personnel in Maldives for medical evacuation and counter-drug trafficking purposes. The Indian government confirmed that the two governments would discuss workable solutions for continued cooperation. Muizzu's request is part of the larger debate in Maldives about the role of foreign powers, particularly China and India. China has been deepening its ties with Maldives in recent years, while India considers Maldives part of its regional sphere of influence. The 'India out' campaign, which alleged that India had sent a large military contingent to Maldives, was prominent during Muizzu's election campaign. However, India and Maldives have also deepened cooperation in other areas, including the development of a harbour and the greater male connectivity project.

item.title: FedEx chief Raj Subramaniam spotted at Xi Jinping dinner with US CEOs: Who is the Indian-American executive?
item.description: Raj Subramaniam, CEO and president of FedEx, attended a gala reception in San Francisco hosted by the US-China Business Council and the National Committee on US-China Relations. Subramaniam has been with FedEx since 1991 and has held various leadership roles within the company. He is responsible for providing strategic direction for all FedEx operating companies. Subramaniam serves on the board of directors for several organizations, including FedEx Corporation and the US-China Business Council. He has over 30 years of industry experience and is recognized for his international leadership and business insights.

item.title: How Vladimir Putin has resorted to homophobia to consolidate his hold on Russia
item.description:
The Russian Ministry of Justice has filed a lawsuit with the Supreme Court to ban the LGBTQ+ "international public movement" due to alleged extremist activities and incitement of social and religious conflict. The lawsuit's target is unclear, whether it aims at specific organizations or the entire LGBTQ+ community. Experts express concerns that this legal action could lead to widespread persecution of LGBTQ+ individuals in Russia, resulting in criminal prosecution based solely on sexual orientation or gender identity.
This move follows a decade-long crackdown on gay rights under President Vladimir Putin's regime, which emphasizes "traditional family values." In 2013, Russia implemented the controversial "gay propaganda" law, prohibiting the non-critical portrayal of "nontraditional sexual relations" among minors. This law was later expanded to include all adults by December 2022.
As support for the prolonged Ukrainian campaign wavered domestically, the Kremlin intensified its homophobia to further the dichotomy between the "decadent" West and Putin's regime, which claimed to protect traditional values. The Russian Orthodox Church, led by Patriarch Kirill and a longstanding Putin ally, supported this anti-LGBTQ+ crusade by linking it to issues like Ukraine's rejection of gay pride parades.
The Russian Orthodox Church, with over 100 million followers in the country, historically maintains close ties with the Kremlin. Conservative movements often use LGBTQ+ rights as punching bags, characterizing them as threats to traditional values. For authoritarian populists, these rights become Trojan horses that help consolidate power by polarizing the debate between gay rights and "family values."
After the Soviet Union's fall, Russia experienced a period of liberalization socially and economically, including progress in LGBTQ+ rights. However, discontent arising from this liberalization, such as poverty and corruption, contributed to the rise of Vladimir Putin and his conservative agenda. Putin's strategic conservatism relies on appeals to faith, family, and tradition, which have been historically used by dictators as a last resort to maintain control.
Overall, the lawsuit against the LGBTQ+ movement in Russia raises concerns about potential persecution and criminalization of sexual orientation and gender identity, adding to the ongoing crackdown on gay rights under Putin's regime.

item.title: Why Osama bin Laden’s 2002 ‘Letter to America’ is gaining traction on social media now

item.title: How the mandatory reporting provision under POCSO works
item.description:
The Himachal Pradesh High Court has ruled that failure to report sexual crimes against minors is a bailable offense. The ruling came in the case of a hotel manager who was accused of failing to report an offense committed against a minor, as mandated by the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act. The court stated that since the act does not specify whether the offense is bailable or not, the nature of the offense must be determined based on the Code of Criminal Procedure. According to the classification of offenses under the Code, offenses punishable with imprisonment of less than three years are bailable and non-cognizable. Since Section 21 of the POCSO Act prescribes imprisonment of 6 months to a year, the court deemed it a bailable offense.
In the case at hand, the main accused raped and recorded a video of a minor schoolgirl in a hotel. He was booked under various sections of the Indian Penal Code, as well as under Sections 6 and 21 of the POCSO Act. The hotel manager was also named in the First Information Report (FIR) due to the mandatory reporting provision under the POCSO Act.
The POCSO Act mandates that anyone who has knowledge or apprehension of an offense under the act must report it to the police or special juvenile police unit (SJPU). Failure to report such offenses is punishable with imprisonment of six months to one year, or a fine, or both. Notably, children cannot be held liable for failing to report sexual offenses.
The Supreme Court has previously held that failure to report sexual crimes against minors is a serious crime. In a 2013 ruling, the court stated that the non-reporting of such crimes is a serious offense. The court has also placed a greater obligation on certain professionals, such as medical practitioners and those in charge of educational institutions, to report cases of child sexual abuse.
A recent Supreme Court ruling attempted to strike a balance between the mandatory reporting provision under the POCSO Act and the confidentiality provision under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act. The court recognized that minors or their guardians might be reluctant to seek out registered medical practitioners for safe termination of pregnancies due to the mandatory reporting requirement. To address this, the court exempted registered medical practitioners from disclosing the minor's identity and personal details when providing medical termination of pregnancy, to prevent any conflict between the statutory obligation to report under the POCSO Act and the minor's privacy and reproductive autonomy.

item.title: COP28 in Dubai: What to expect from climate meeting
item.description:
The upcoming COP28 conference in Dubai is expected to address the inadequate collective commitment of nations in combating climate change. Climate change impacts have been evident for years, and this year is set to be the warmest ever recorded. Current climate action plans are projected to result in only a 2% reduction in emissions by 2030, far from the necessary 43% reduction recommended by the IPCC for the goal of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius.
A UN report highlights the declining availability of funds for developing countries to invest in adaptation measures, with only $21 billion flowing in compared to the required $215 billion annually. Financial resources remain a challenge for these countries, despite facing the highest climate risks. While short-term solutions to halt climate deterioration may be limited, the focus is on avoiding a completely hopeless situation.
Tripling the world's installed capacity of renewable energy by 2030 is a crucial objective. This would significantly increase the generation of electricity from renewable sources, accounting for nearly 70% of total electricity compared to the current 28%. The International Energy Agency estimates that achieving this could avoid 7 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions by 2030.
The proposal to triple renewable energy capacity has already received support from G20 countries, and more countries are expected to endorse it at the Dubai meeting. However, the issue of climate finance remains unresolved, as developed countries failed to meet their promise of mobilizing $100 billion annually from 2020. While progress on this goal would be an achievement, the challenge lies in raising additional funds beyond $100 billion each year.
The creation of a loss and damage fund, intended to assist countries affected by climate change impacts, was a positive outcome of the previous climate meeting. Although the fund was established last year, no funding has been provided yet. The Dubai conference aims to allocate some funds to address the concerns of small island countries, who would benefit the most from this fund.
The meeting in Dubai will also feature the presentation of findings from the first stocktake exercise, which assesses countries' progress in fighting climate change and identifies future actions. The phase-down or phase-out of fossil fuels, particularly coal, remains a contentious issue that is unlikely to be resolved at the conference.
Overall, while the current level of commitment to climate action is insufficient, COP28 in Dubai is expected to deliver meaningful outcomes such as increased renewable energy capacity, potential funding for the loss and damage fund, and discussions on future actions against climate change.

The junta remains in control of Central Myanmar, while the resistance in Shan State appears to be receiving tacit support from China. The rebels' objective is to eradicate the military dictatorship, and the operation seems to have gained some Chinese support due to an incident that infuriated China involving guards at a scam compound.
India, while expressing concern about the interruption of democracy in Myanmar, has walked a fine line between engagement with the junta and protecting its interests.
