The study highlights the importance of mitigating the impacts of climate change, as the melting of the West Antarctic ice sheet is just one contributor to rising sea levels.

item.title: Rajnath Singh talks about ‘prisoner’s dilemma’ in international relations: What is this concept
item.description: During his keynote address at the Goa Maritime Conclave, Defence Minister Rajnath Singh highlighted the importance of collaboration and trust between countries in international relations. He referred to the concept of "Prisoner's Dilemma" to explain the strategic decision-making challenges faced by countries. The Prisoner's Dilemma is a game in Game Theory that demonstrates how individuals or entities behave under different circumstances and aims to achieve the best outcome. Singh emphasized the need to find solutions that promote cooperation, build trust, and mitigate the risks associated with the Prisoner's Dilemma situations. The article provides examples of how this concept applies to scenarios such as an arms race between countries or competition between companies in the market. It concludes by suggesting that countries should establish ground rules in geopolitics to avoid detrimental consequences for their economies and people.

item.title: Rajnath Singh talks about ‘prisoner’s dilemma’ in international relations: What is this concept
item.description: Defence Minister Rajnath Singh spoke about the concept of "Prisoner's Dilemma" during his keynote address at the Goa Maritime Conclave. He explained that this concept can be applied to international relations to understand situations where countries face strategic decision-making challenges. Singh emphasized the need for countries to collaborate and build trust instead of engaging in an arms race out of fear and mistrust. Prisoner's Dilemma is a popular game in Game Theory that helps understand how people or entities behave under different circumstances. It highlights the paradox of whether to confess or stay silent in a situation where two prisoners are questioned about a crime. The best outcome lies in cooperation, but the dilemma has real-life applications in international law and business, such as setting ground rules to avoid an arms race or agreeing on prices to ensure healthy profits.

item.title: Electoral bonds: What Govt, RBI, ECI said when the scheme was first proposed
item.description: The Supreme Court of India will begin hearing petitions challenging the Electoral Bonds Scheme, 2018, which allows anonymous donations to political parties. According to the State Bank of India, the only bank authorized to sell the bonds, around Rs 13,000 crore has been transferred through the scheme since March 2018. The scheme was proposed by Arun Jaitley in 2017, despite concerns raised by the Reserve Bank of India and the Election Commission of India. The government argues that the scheme promotes transparency and accountability in political funding, while the RBI and ECI have raised concerns about potential misuse and lack of transparency.

item.title: The moon is 40 million years older: What a new study says
item.description: Scientists have made a groundbreaking discovery about the age of the moon, finding that it is older than previously thought. A new study used a technology called atom probe tomography to analyze crystals from a lunar sample collected 51 years ago. They found that the moon formed about 4.46 billion years ago, within the first 110 million years of the birth of our solar system. This research challenges previous estimates and provides valuable information about the formation of the earth-moon system. The study highlights the importance of nanoscale spatial resolution in understanding big-picture questions about the universe. The age of the moon, at 4.46 billion years, puts it only slightly younger than the estimated age of the earth.

item.title: Why the Lewis Model on labour and industrialisation has worked in China, not in India
item.description: The article discusses the concept of industrialization in underdeveloped countries with surplus labor populations, as proposed by economist William Arthur Lewis. Lewis argued that a growing manufacturing sector could absorb the surplus labor from agriculture and other subsistence sectors by offering higher wages. However, the model has not played out as expected in India. While the share of employment in agriculture has decreased, it has not been replaced by significant growth in manufacturing. Instead, most new jobs have been created in low-paid services and construction. The movement of labor has mainly occurred within subsistence sectors rather than a shift to capitalist sectors. The exception is Gujarat, where a significant proportion of the workforce is employed in manufacturing. However, even in Gujarat, the proportion of workers in agriculture is still high compared to other states. The article suggests that the traditional model of labor transition from agriculture to industry needs to be rethought due to increasing capital-intensive manufacturing and technological advancements. NITI Aayog, an Indian government think tank, is exploring new economic development models that focus on creating remunerative jobs related to agriculture but outside the farm, such as in processing, packaging, transportation, and retailing of agricultural produce or supplying inputs and services to farmers.

item.title: From 2016 to present, how Maratha morcha changed its stance, modes of protest over reservation demand
item.description: The Maratha Kranti Morcha (MKM) has evolved from a socio-economic issue to a political movement centered around the demand for reservation. Maratha activist Manoj Jarange Patil, who is on a hunger strike, has warned the government to find a solution to the issue. Other Maratha activists have shown solidarity with Patil through candlelight protests. Deputy Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis has urged Patil to prioritize his health and trust in the government's commitment to reservation. The Maratha reservation issue gained momentum in 2016 after the alleged rape and killing of a teenage girl from the community. The MKM's demands also include action against the perpetrators of the crime, higher remuneration for farmers, and loan waivers. The MKM emphasizes peaceful protests and aims to achieve justice for the Maratha community.

item.title: Hamas leader addresses rally in Kerala virtually: Who is Khaled Mashal?
item.description: Former head of Hamas, Khaled Mashal, virtually addressed a pro-Palestine rally in Kerala's Malappuram, calling for unity for Gaza. He spoke about the ongoing conflict in the region and criticized Israel for demolishing houses, churches, temples, universities, and UN institutions. Mashal was born in the West Bank town of Silwad in 1956 and became a member of Hamas, a militant organization that used violence for the cause of Palestine. He headed Hamas's Politburo from 1996 to 2017 and currently leads the group's 'external' politburo based in Qatar. Mashal echoed Hamas's opposition to Israel but stated in a 2017 document that they accepted the idea of a Palestinian state within the territories occupied by Israel in the Six-day War of 1967. He also discussed the possibility of negotiating with Israel when they are strong enough to create a reality that forces Israel to reconsider its positions. Mashal has called for unity against Israel following recent attacks and counter-attacks between Hamas and Israel. He was targeted in an Israeli assassination attempt in 1997, which led to a crisis between Jordan and Israel.

item.title: India bans exports of some rice varieties: How this has impacted prices globally, in the country
item.description:
According to an article from The Indian Express, India banned the export of non-basmati white rice in July 2023 due to depleting public stock, elevated cereal prices, and the threat of an uneven monsoon. The First Advance Estimates of major Kharif crops for 2023-24, released by the Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers’ Welfare, showed a 3.7% decrease in rice production compared to the previous year [[SOURCE 1]].
The ban on non-basmati white rice exports led to a sharp increase in rice prices across markets. Although prices have come down since then, they are still higher than the pre-ban period. The impact of India's export restrictions on rice supply, availability, and prices has been felt both domestically and globally [[SOURCE 1]].
Despite the export ban, there has been no respite from the increase in domestic rice prices. The daily average wholesale price of rice on October 24, 2023, was 27.43% higher than a month ago. The daily average retail price of rice on the same day was 12.59% higher than a year ago [[SOURCE 1]].
India is the largest exporter of rice in the world, accounting for about 40% of total rice exports in 2022. Rice exports from India are broadly categorized into basmati and non-basmati rice. While the ban applies to non-basmati white rice and broken rice, there is no ban on other sub-categories of rice [[SOURCE 1]].
In the financial year 2022-23, India exported 45.61 lakh metric tonnes of basmati rice to various countries, with Iran, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, UAE, and Yemen being the top destinations. For non-basmati rice, India exported 177.91 lakh metric tonnes, with Benin, Madagascar, and Kenya being the top buyers. The ban on non-basmati white rice and broken rice exports has significantly affected the quantity of rice shipped out and the number of countries importing from India [[SOURCE 1]].
The article also provides information on other categories of rice exports, such as par-boiled rice, husked (brown) rice, rice in husk of seed quality, and other rice in husk. It mentions the quantities exported and the top importing countries for each category [[SOURCE 1]].
In terms of rice procurement and requirement, the total production of rice during 2022-23 is estimated to be 1357.55 lakh tonnes, which is higher than the previous year's production. The government has been procuring paddy from various states for the Kharif marketing season. The total rice stock in the Central Pool as of October 1, 2023, is 221.87 lakh metric tonnes [[SOURCE 1]].
In summary, India's ban on the export of non-basmati white rice has had a significant impact on rice prices both domestically and globally. Despite the ban, domestic rice prices have continued to rise. India remains a major player in the global rice market, with significant exports of basmati and non-basmati rice.

item.title: Why new tax filing data shows better compliance, upward mobility in higher-income slabs
item.description:
Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.According to the latest income tax returns statistics released by the Income Tax Department, there has been wider compliance and a shift in taxpayers towards higher-income slabs from lower-income slabs. In the assessment year 2021-22, a total of 6.75 crore taxpayers filed income tax returns, which is a rise of 5.6% from the previous year. Additionally, around 2.1 crore taxpayers paid taxes but did not file returns. The data also shows that the share of taxpayers paying nil tax has increased over the years, reaching 66% in the assessment year 2021-22. However, the proportionate contribution of gross total income of the top 1% individual taxpayers has decreased from 15.9% in the assessment year 2013-14 to 14.6% in the assessment year 2021-22.
The income tax statistics also reveal that the highest rate of growth for salaried individual taxpayers was seen in the income slabs of Rs 15-20 lakh and Rs 20-25 lakh in the financial year 2020-21. On the other hand, the lower-income slabs of Rs 10-15 lakh and Rs 5-10 lakh recorded lower growth rates. It is worth noting that the financial year 2020-21 was affected by the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.
The data further shows that around 67,970 individuals in India disclosed salary income over Rs 1 crore in the assessment year 2021-22, which is an increase of 3.9% from the previous year. Out of these individuals, 16 had a salary between Rs 100-500 crore.
Overall, the income tax returns statistics indicate a positive trend of migration to higher ranges of gross total income among individual taxpayers. However, concerns remain about the significant number of taxpayers who pay taxes but do not file returns

item.title: An Expert Explains | 10 years of China’s Belt and Road Initiative: The project, its aims and where it stands now
item.description:
The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is a decade-old infrastructure funding project initiated by China's President Xi Jinping. It aims to connect Asia, Africa, and Europe through investments worth billions of dollars. The BRI initially consisted of the Silk Road Economic 'Belt' and the sea trade infrastructure called 'Road'. Over time, it expanded to include six international Economic Corridors.
Criticism has been raised regarding the sustainability of the debts incurred by BRI projects. Some countries, such as India and the United States, have accused China of engaging in 'debt trap diplomacy' by aiming to acquire assets if loan repayment becomes impossible.
Despite the criticism, the BRI has attracted significant participation from over 150 countries and 30 international organizations. Currently, more than 3,000 BRI projects valued at $1 trillion are underway globally.
The article highlights concerns about transparency, debt traps, and sustainability of BRI projects. It also discusses the evolving perceptions of the European Union (EU) and the United States towards the initiative. While the EU initially viewed the BRI positively, growing apprehensions have led to a reassessment of the relationship with China.
The China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) is a flagship BRI project, strengthening the strategic partnership between China and Pakistan. Despite concerns about its long-term impact on Pakistan's economy, it is unlikely that Pakistan will abandon the CPEC.
India has consistently expressed reservations about the BRI due to sovereignty-related issues and geopolitical implications. China's expanding economic presence in South Asia, including investments in ports, has concerned Indian policymakers.
Geopolitical tensions, particularly the measures taken by the US and Europe to reduce economic dependence on China, could impact the Chinese economy and the expansion of the BRI. Consequently, China may need to re-strategize some of its BRI projects.
Despite criticism, the BRI has given China diplomatic and geopolitical leverage within the Global South. Western countries are still searching for alternatives to BRI in terms of infrastructure investments.
In response to the challenging geopolitical and economic landscape, China is adjusting its ambitions and focusing on green and smaller-scale development projects. The success of other China-led initiatives, such as the Global Security Initiative and the Global Development Initiative, largely depends on the BRI's success.

item.title: Kerala blast: Who are Jehovah’s Witnesses
item.description: Two people were killed and several others injured in a series of blasts at a Jehovah's Witnesses prayer convention near Kochi. The incident occurred at the Zamra International Convention and Exhibition Centre, where around 2,500 faithful had gathered for a prayer session. A man named Dominic Martin, an estranged member of Jehovah's Witnesses, claimed responsibility for the attack in a video posted on social media. He stated that he believed the sect's teachings were anti-national and wanted them to change their ideology. Jehovah's Witnesses are a Christian sect that does not believe in the Holy Trinity and worships Jehovah as the one true God. They base their beliefs solely on the Bible and do not celebrate Christmas or Easter. The sect is known for its evangelical work and believes that the end of the world is near. In India, Jehovah's Witnesses have faced legal challenges regarding their refusal to sing the national anthem or participate in certain activities due to their religious beliefs. The Supreme Court has granted protection to members of the sect in cases involving their right to freedom of religion.

item.title: Israel-Hamas war: Where the conflict goes from here, and how it could affect the global economy
item.description: The Israel Defence Forces (IDF) are expanding their ground activity in the Gaza Strip as part of their plan to destroy Hamas. However, it remains unclear how Israel will handle the post-conflict phase if they succeed in eliminating Hamas. General David Petraeus, a former CIA director and top US general, warned Israel against making mistakes in planning for the post-conflict phase, citing the US's own mistakes in Iraq. He emphasized the importance of having a vision for the future of Gaza and the Palestinian people after Hamas is destroyed. Petraeus also cautioned that Israel's bombing campaign and land invasion could lead to a situation similar to the battle of Mogadishu in Somalia in 1993. The military engagement between Israel and Hamas could have serious economic consequences for the region and the world, particularly if it escalates into a full-scale war involving regional powers like Iran. A direct conflict between Iran and Israel could push crude oil prices above $150 per barrel, leading to global inflation and slower economic growth. Even a regional conflict confined to the Gaza Strip could have negative impacts on the global economy as it emerges from multiple shocks.

item.title: Ukraine, G20, Gaza: Over deep faultlines, New Delhi walks diplomatic tightrope again
item.description: India's abstention at the UN General Assembly on the resolution for a ceasefire in Gaza reflects its attempt to address competing priorities in the ongoing conflict. India joined Australia, Canada, Germany, Japan, Ukraine, and the United Kingdom in abstaining. The resolution, proposed by Jordan and supported by Arab countries, called for a humanitarian truce and unhindered humanitarian access to the Gaza Strip. France voted in favor of the resolution but expressed regret that it did not address terrorist attacks by Hamas. Israel, the United States, and four Eastern European countries voted against the resolution. Canada proposed an amendment to hold Hamas responsible, but it was not adopted. UN General Assembly resolutions are not legally binding, but the resolution carries moral authority. India's stance aligns with its approach to the Russia-Ukraine war, using diplomatic tools to maintain a balancing act. India's explanation of vote emphasizes its support for Israel regarding attacks on its civilians and concern for the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

item.title: What is the ‘SIM swap scam’ — and how can you protect yourself?
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The SIM swap scam is a growing problem in Delhi, India, where fraudsters steal personal information and use it to obtain duplicate SIM cards. The scam involves fraudsters taking personal details through phishing or vishing techniques, then posing as the victim at a mobile operator's retail outlet to report a fake theft of the victim's SIM card. With a duplicate SIM, the fraudsters can receive banking authorization messages and OTPs (one-time passwords) to initiate transactions and steal money from victims' bank accounts. Victims often receive multiple missed calls from the fraudsters to distract them and make them ignore their phones. The stolen money is typically routed through different channels, including conversion to cryptocurrency, making it difficult for police to track. To protect against this scam, individuals should be cautious about sharing personal information and regularly check their bank alerts and messages.

item.title: Swiss woman’s murder in Delhi: How the police deals with the murder of foreign nationals
item.description: The article discusses the murder of a Swiss national named Nina Berger in West Delhi. Berger's body was found decomposing behind a school, with her hands and legs chained and bruises all over. A businessman named Gurpreet, who was reportedly Berger's scorned lover, has been arrested for the crime. However, Berger's family in Zurich has not physically identified the body, putting the burden of evidence solely on Gurpreet. The family has given consent for a postmortem to be carried out in their absence. The article explores the complications that arise when dealing with the murder of foreign nationals and how the police handle such cases. It explains the process of verifying the victim's identity and informing their next of kin through the embassy. In cases where the body remains unidentified, the police generally wait for a few weeks before disposing of it as per the standard procedure. Berger's family has provided circumstantial evidence but has refused to come to Delhi to physically identify the body and cooperate with the investigation. One possible option to identify the body is through DNA testing or by seeking information from the family in Switzerland. The article emphasizes the importance of physical identification in building a case but also highlights the role of circumstantial evidence in proving the case before courts. The police will rely on other material collected to confirm the deceased's identity and states that if the family wants to join the investigation or take Berger's remains back home, they will be given a piece of cloth or ashes, depending on the chosen method of disposal.

item.title: What’s behind the current J&K power crisis — and how the administration plans to address it
item.description: The Jammu & Kashmir administration is facing a power crisis as its power projects are generating less electricity due to a dry spell in summer. Currently, J&K only generates 3,263 MW of electricity from 21 power projects, compared to its identified power generation potential of 16,475 MW. The deficit in power supply is about 500 MW, with a requirement of about 2,600 MW of electricity. The administration is taking steps to address the issue, such as purchasing an additional 700 MW of electricity at a higher cost and promoting the use of ad cables to prevent theft. Efforts are also being made to install meters in all areas to minimize power cuts. The administration has approved a green energy corridor project that will reduce J&K's dependence on hydropower.

item.title: Why Jharkhand govt has approved a new Rs 1,600 crore housing scheme
item.description: The Jharkhand Cabinet has approved the 'Abua Awas Yojna' (AAY), a housing scheme for the poor in the state. The scheme aims to provide eight lakh pucca houses to the homeless with a budget of Rs 1,6320 crore. It will be implemented in three phases, targeting two lakh houses in the current financial year, 3.5 lakh houses in FY 2024-25, and 2.5 lakh houses in FY 2025-26. The scheme was needed because existing government schemes have been unable to cover all eligible beneficiaries. The state government found that around eight lakh eligible beneficiaries had been left out of housing schemes due to discrepancies in the database. Despite repeated requests to the central government, these beneficiaries were not added to the list. Therefore, the state decided to create its own housing scheme. Under the AAY, beneficiaries will receive a three-room and one kitchen house with a total area of 31 sq m. The government has allocated Rs 2 lakh per beneficiary, to be disbursed in four installments. There is also a provision for beneficiaries to work under the MGNREGS and receive wages for building the house. Additionally, a toilet can be added to the house using funds from the Swaccha Bharat Mission or other available schemes. All houses built under the AAY will be registered in the name of women in the beneficiary families. The scheme will benefit people belonging to six categories, and a list of beneficiaries will be prepared based on specific criteria.

item.title: The United Nations General Assembly vote on Gaza war, and why India abstained
item.description: India abstained from a UN General Assembly vote on a resolution calling for a humanitarian truce in the Israel-Hamas conflict. The resolution, which did not mention Hamas or hostages, was passed with 120 votes in favor and 14 against. India voted in favor of an amendment proposed by Canada that named Hamas, but the amendment failed to get the necessary support. India's abstention reflects its balancing act in the ongoing conflict. The article highlights four key takeaways from the UNGA proceedings and India's response. First, India joined a group of 45 countries that abstained from the resolution. Second, India supported the amendment proposed by Canada, but it was not adopted. Third, resolutions of the UNGA are not legally binding, but they carry moral weight. Fourth, India's balanced position is consistent with its approach to other conflicts, such as the Russia-Ukraine war. The article also provides details of India's statement at the UNGA, which called for dialogue and condemned violence while expressing concern for civilian casualties and advocating for a negotiated two-state solution.

item.title: Decorated officers and specialists: The 8 Navy veterans sentenced to death in Qatar
item.description: Eight retired veterans of the Indian Navy, who were working for an Omani private defense consultancy called Dahra Global, have been sentenced to death by a Qatari court. The reasons for their arrest and death penalty have not been made public, but there is speculation that they may have been involved in espionage for a foreign state. The Indian Ministry of External Affairs has expressed shock at the verdict and is exploring all legal options. The article provides some background information on each of the eight men, including their previous positions and accomplishments in the Indian Navy. One of them is the son of a retired army officer and served on India's second aircraft carrier. Another received commendations from the commander-in-chief twice and worked briefly at Hindustan Shipyard after retiring. Another veteran, who was awarded the Pravasi Bharatiya Samman award, trained Singapore naval personnel before moving to Qatar. Two of the veterans specialized in navigation, one in communications, and one in gunnery, while one was a sailor.

item.title: Why is Qatar playing mediator between the US and Hamas?
item.description: Qatar has played a crucial role in facilitating the release of hostages held by Hamas, including the recent release of an American-Israeli mother-daughter pair. The United States has expressed gratitude to Qatar for its involvement in these efforts. Qatar is a small country in the Persian Gulf and is both a close ally of the United States and known to have ties with Hamas. This unique position allows Qatar to act as a mediator in conflicts and as a proxy for the US and other Western countries when direct engagement is not possible. Qatar's geopolitical dynamics have changed significantly over the years due to factors such as its booming economy fueled by natural gas reserves, its increasing closeness with the US, and the ascension of Sheikh Hamad to power. Qatar has also asserted its independence in the international arena, maintaining relations with Iran and providing support to actors opposed to certain Arab governments during the Arab Spring. However, Qatar's actions have led to tensions with neighboring Arab states, resulting in a trade and diplomatic embargo in 2017. Despite this, Qatar remains a significant player in the region due to its natural gas reserves and its hosting of the largest American base in the Middle East.

item.title: The centrality of natural gas in ties between India and Qatar
item.description:
The article discusses the death sentence given to eight former personnel of the Indian Navy by a court in Qatar and its implications on the India-Qatar relationship. It highlights the significant trade imbalance between the two countries, with imports from Qatar outweighing India's exports. The trade between India and Qatar is heavily dominated by liquefied natural gas (LNG), which accounts for over half of India's overall import volumes of the fuel. India's import dependency on natural gas is around 50%, and with the government's aim to increase natural gas consumption, imports are expected to rise in the future. Qatar holds a significant leverage in the trade relationship due to its dominance in the LNG market.
India's largest LNG importer, Petronet LNG, has a long-term contract with Qatar for the import of 8.5 million tonnes per annum (mtpa) of LNG. India has set an ambitious target to increase the share of natural gas in its primary energy mix, which will result in further growth in LNG imports. Natural gas is seen as a cleaner alternative to conventional petroleum fuels and is cheaper than crude oil. Given India's energy security concerns and ambitions, the case of the retired navy personnel presents a sensitive challenge for Indian diplomacy.
In FY2022-23, India's total imports from Qatar were valued at $16.81 billion, with LNG imports accounting for 49.5% of the total. India's other major imports from Qatar include liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), plastics, and petrochemicals. On the other hand, India's exports to Qatar were valued at just $1.97 billion in the same period. India imported 10.74 million tonnes of LNG from Qatar, representing 54% of the total LNG imports. Despite efforts to diversify sourcing, it may take several years to reduce the reliance on Qatar for LNG imports.
The global LNG market has become a seller's market due to disruptions in Russian natural gas supplies to Europe. The spot LNG market is prone to price volatility, while term contracts provide a more stable and reasonable price. Qatar, as the world's largest exporter of LNG, holds a strong position in the market. Many countries, including India, are looking to secure long-term contracts with major suppliers like Qatar. The article also mentions that the global LNG market may eventually turn into a buyer's market due to new LNG export projects, but this is still years away.
Overall, the article highlights the significance of the India-Qatar trade relationship, especially in terms of LNG imports, and the challenges India faces in diversifying its energy sources and reducing reliance on Qatar.

item.title: What is West Bengal’s alleged PDS scam, in which ED has arrested TMC Minister Jyotipriya Mallick?
item.description: West Bengal Forest Minister Jyotipriya Mallick has been arrested by the Enforcement Directorate (ED) for his alleged involvement in the state's Public Distribution System (PDS) scam. The scam involves the illegal distribution of rice and wheat, where Mallick and businessman Bakibur Rahman are said to be involved. Rahman would supply lesser quantities of grains to distributors, who would then sell them at lower prices to the poor. The remaining balance would be sold in the open market for profit. The ED had previously arrested Rahman and conducted search operations at various locations connected to him. This PDS scam is one of several alleged scams involving the Trinamool Congress (TMC) party in West Bengal, including cases related to recruitment, smuggling, and coal. The ED document reveals details about the scam, stating that mill owners collected money from the government for selling grains but supplied lesser quantities. The profit from this mismatch in distribution was divided between suppliers, mill owners, government officials, and the Minister's office. Irregularities in the PDS distribution were first flagged during the Covid-19 pandemic in May 2020, leading to protests and criticism from both the Central government and West Bengal Governor Jagdeep Dhankhar. The West Bengal government denied these allegations but faced mounting troubles as evidence emerged.

item.title: Li Keqiang was once tipped to be President of China. What happened?
item.description: Former Chinese Premier Li Keqiang has died at the age of 68 after suffering a heart attack. Li was a longtime member of the Chinese Communist Party's (CCP) standing committee of the politburo, the highest policy-making body in the country. He served as premier for a decade before being ousted from the politburo in 2022. Despite his ouster and reduced role in recent years, Li was involved in major aspects of Chinese policy and had a unique position among other Chinese leaders due to his academic background and ability to communicate in English. Li was known for championing the opening up of the Chinese economy and was involved in economic policy. However, his influence and power declined under President Xi Jinping, who consolidated power and sidelined Li's faction within the CCP. Li's tenure also saw criticism, including questions about his performance during his provincial governorships and a public perception of "bad luck." Despite his efforts, the concentration of power under Xi limited Li's ability to enact economic reforms. Li will likely be remembered for his concern for the welfare of ordinary people, but also for what could have been.

item.title: Inform customers when banks ask for their credit score: What RBI has told credit bureaus
item.description: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has instructed credit information companies (CICs) to notify customers via SMS or email when their Credit Information Report (CIR) is accessed by banks and non-banking finance companies (NBFCs). Additionally, banks and NBFCs must send alerts to customers when they submit information on default or Days Past Due (DPD) on existing credit. These new rules will be implemented within six months. CICs collect and analyze credit information from banks and NBFCs to calculate credit scores for individuals and credit ranks for companies. A high credit score increases the chances of obtaining a loan at a favorable rate, while a low score may result in loan denial. The RBI has also mandated that CICs provide individuals with a free full credit report, including credit score, once a year. Customers can apply for data correction if they believe their information is incorrect, and CICs must inform customers of the reasons for data correction rejections. CICs should conduct periodic reviews of their search and match logic algorithm and disclose complaint details on their websites.

item.title: Israel-Hamas conflict: 10 takeaways from a stay in the war zone
item.description: The article discusses the current conflict between Israel and Hamas, highlighting the raw brutality of the attacks and the high number of hostages held by Hamas. It also mentions the devastating impact on both Israeli and Palestinian civilians, with airstrikes destroying Gaza City and forcing people to flee. The article notes that Israelis feel a sense of betrayal from their government's lack of preparedness, and there is a growing desire for revenge and retribution. The future of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is uncertain, as opposition parties rally against him. The article also speculates on what may happen after Hamas is destroyed, suggesting that an Arab coalition, possibly led by Jordan, could take charge of Gaza. It mentions the potential impact on regional dynamics, including the normalisation process between Saudi Arabia and Israel. India's position in the conflict is discussed, as it has relationships with both Israel and Arab countries in the region. The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of India's diplomatic efforts in maintaining its relationships and ensuring the well-being of its diaspora and energy security.

item.title: Qatar court sentences 8 Indian Navy veterans to death: A timeline of the case
item.description: Eight former personnel of the Indian Navy have been sentenced to death by a Qatari court. The men were working for a private company overseeing the induction of submarines in the Qatari Emiri Naval Force. The reasons for their arrest and the alleged crime they have been sentenced for are not publicly known. The Indian government has been closely monitoring the situation and providing support to the arrested sailors. India has maintained a stance in accordance with international laws, similar to the Enrica Lexie-Italian Marines case. The families of the former Navy personnel have also filed a Mercy Plea to the Emir of Qatar.

item.title: India’s 800-year-old connection with Jerusalem: Baba Farid’s lodge, now a rest stop for Indian travellers
item.description: The Indian Hospice in Jerusalem has a long history dating back to the 12th century. Legend has it that Baba Farid, a Sufi saint from Punjab, spent time meditating at this spot, and over time it became a shrine and hospice for Indian Muslims visiting Jerusalem. The lodge within the hospice, known as Zawiya Al-Hindiya, has retained its association with India despite changing rulers. In the early 20th century, the lodge underwent renovations and repairs with the help of Muslim patrons from India. After India gained independence, the lodge sought official recognition from the Indian embassy in Egypt. Today, the Indian Hospice continues to serve as a sanctuary for travelers and pilgrims from India and hosts various organizations within its premises. The property is owned by the Waqf Board of India and is accessible only to individuals of Indian citizenship or heritage.

item.title: Who are the 8 Indian Navy veterans sentenced to death by a court in Qatar, and what is the case against them?
item.description: Eight former Indian Navy personnel have been sentenced to death by a court in Qatar. The reasons for their arrest and the awarding of the death penalty are not known, and their families were not informed of the charges against them. The case poses a significant diplomatic challenge for the Indian government. The veterans were working at a defense services provider company owned by an Omani national, who was also arrested but later released. The company had connections to the Qatari Emiri Naval Force, but its new website does not mention this or the former Navy officers who held leadership roles. The arrested men had been working at the company for several years before their arrests. The charges against them were never made public, but they were put in solitary confinement, leading to speculation of a security-related offense. India and Qatar have had friendly relations for many years, with strong trade and defense cooperation ties. This incident is the second major challenge to the relationship in recent years, following a controversy over derogatory remarks about the Prophet Muhammad made by a BJP spokesperson. The news of the death penalty comes at a time when tensions are high in the Middle East due to the Israeli bombardment of Gaza, and Qatar is playing a role as a mediator in the crisis.

item.title: Why have 33 US states sued Meta?
item.description: Dozens of US states have filed a lawsuit against Meta, the parent company of Instagram and Facebook, alleging that the tech giant has contributed to the youth mental health crisis. The attorneys general of 33 states, including California and New York, claim that Meta repeatedly misled the public about the dangers of its platforms and intentionally encouraged young people to engage in addictive and compulsive social media use. The lawsuit comes two years after former Meta employee Frances Haugen blew the whistle on the company, revealing an internal study that showed many young girls on Instagram suffering from depression and anxiety related to body image issues. The lawsuit specifically mentions features such as likes, alerts, and filters, which are known to promote body dysmorphia in young users. Meta has denied the allegations and expressed disappointment that the attorneys general chose to pursue legal action instead of collaborating with the industry to establish clearer standards for apps used by teens. Haugen's testimony to Congress and internal documents she released have also been cited in the lawsuit, which highlights the negative impact of Instagram on teenagers' mental health. The research on social media's adverse effects, including increased levels of anxiety and depression, has been well-documented.

item.title: Three reasons why Israel has still not launched its ground offensive into Gaza
item.description: Israel's Defence Minister Yoav Gallant has stated that the country will launch a ground offensive into Gaza following an air offensive by the Israeli Defence Forces (IDF). However, there are several reasons why Israel has not yet initiated a full-scale ground invasion. Firstly, the US administration under President Joe Biden has reportedly advised Israel to delay the invasion in order to strategize and prevent excessive loss of civilian lives. The US has requested time to complete preparations for a broader conflict, including deploying air defense systems in the Gulf and sending an aircraft carrier and marines. Additionally, there are over 200 hostages being held in unknown locations in Gaza, making it unlikely that Israel could rescue all of them by force. The delay in the ground offensive may be an attempt to negotiate for more hostage releases before launching a military operation. Furthermore, Gaza's extensive network of underground tunnels poses a challenge for Israeli forces. These tunnels house Hamas command centers, stockpile weapons, and potentially hold hostages. Previous attempts to bomb the tunnels have been unsuccessful. The IDF is concerned about endangering the safety of hostages if they strike the tunnel network. The complexity of eliminating Hamas' infrastructure in Gaza is another factor holding Israel back. Former UN weapons inspector Scott Ritter suggests that many of the reservists called up by Israel are not combat-ready and may not be prepared for a conventional ground battle against Hamas. There is also concern about Hezbollah opening a front in southern Lebanon simultaneously with a conflict in Gaza, which would strain Israel's resources and manpower. Iran has warned that it could get involved if the situation worsens in Gaza. Reports of civilian casualties could also escalate Palestinian unrest in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, requiring Israel to allocate additional forces and resources to contain it. Finally, even if Israel were successful in eliminating Hamas from Gaza, it would be challenging to administer the territory long-term as successors to Hamas may be even more radical and extremist.

item.title: What is the ‘One nation, One Student ID’ initiative of the Union govt?
item.description: The Indian government has introduced the Automated Permanent Academic Account Registry (APAAR), a special ID system for all students in India. Under this initiative, each student will receive a lifelong APAAR ID, which will track their academic progress from pre-primary education to higher education. APAAR will also serve as a gateway to Digilocker, a digital system where students can store important documents and achievements. The goal of APAAR is to make education hassle-free and reduce the need for physical documents. It aims to reduce fraud and duplicate certificates by providing a single, trusted reference for educational institutions. Every individual will have a unique APAAR ID linked to the Academic Bank Credit (ABC), which stores information about the credits earned by students. When a student changes schools, their data in the ABC will be transferred to the new school using the APAAR ID, eliminating the need for physical documents. To sign up for APAAR, students will need to provide basic information and their Aadhar number for verification. The government assures that the information shared will be kept confidential and only used for educational purposes. Registration for APAAR is voluntary, not mandatory.

item.title: Who is Nasiruddin Ansari of Baap of Chart, and why has SEBI barred him from the markets?
item.description: The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) has barred Mohammad Nasiruddin Ansari, owner of 'Baap of Chart', from participating in the securities market. Ansari allegedly provided stock recommendations and promised guaranteed returns to investors through social media platforms. SEBI has ordered Ansari to pay back Rs 17.2 crore and cease his activities as an investment advisor. The investigation found that Ansari collected funds from investors through his courses and workshops, as well as through bank accounts linked to him and his company. SEBI has warned investors to be cautious when seeking advice online and to only deal with registered investment advisors.

item.title: Expert Explains | What happens now in Mahua Moitra cash-for-query case: process, precedent
item.description: BJP MP Nishikant Dubey and lawyer Jai Anant Dehadrai will appear before the ethics committee of Lok Sabha on Thursday in connection with Dubey's accusation against Trinamool Congress member Mahua Moitra. Dubey alleged that Moitra accepted bribes to ask questions in parliament that targeted the Adani group. The allegations were based on information provided by Dehadrai and confirmed by real estate developer Darshan Hiranandani. Hiranandani issued a sworn affidavit stating that Moitra gave him her parliament login and password to post questions on her behalf. The question at hand is whether Moitra asked questions in return for consideration and if there is illegal gratification involved. If established, this could be a serious breach of privilege and contempt of the house. The matter should have been referred to the privileges committee, which is responsible for addressing breaches of privilege and contempt of the house. The ethics committee typically deals with questions of propriety but not alleged breaches of privilege. The committee will call the parties involved, including the complainant, witnesses, and Moitra, who has the right to cross-examine the complainant. The committee can recommend suspension, but it does not have executive powers. Its recommendations will go before the house for a decision, which can accept or modify the punishment. If a member is expelled, they can challenge it based on unconstitutionality, gross illegality, or denial of natural justice. The court's intervention in such cases is limited.

item.title: LS Ethics Committee: its constitution, members
item.description: The Lok Sabha Ethics Committee, responsible for handling complaints against members of parliament, last met on July 27, 2021. The committee, which was established over twenty years ago, mostly deals with relatively minor offenses. The members of the committee are appointed by the Speaker for a one-year term, and it is currently headed by Vinod Kumar Sonkar from the BJP. Other members include representatives from various political parties. The idea of ethics panels for both houses was proposed in 1996, and the Rajya Sabha ethics committee was formed in 1997. The Lok Sabha ethics committee was recommended during the 13th Lok Sabha and became a permanent part of the house in 2015. In 2005, motions were adopted to expel several MPs accused of accepting money for asking questions in parliament. The BJP demanded that the report be sent to the privileges committee so that the MPs could defend themselves. Any person can file a complaint against an MP, accompanied by evidence and an affidavit. The committee only entertains complaints that involve misconduct by MPs and conducts a preliminary inquiry before deciding to examine a complaint. After evaluating a complaint, the committee presents its report to the Speaker for consideration. The work of the ethics committee and privileges committee often overlap, with more serious accusations typically going to the privileges committee. The privileges committee's role is to protect the freedom, authority, and dignity of parliament. The ethics committee specifically addresses cases of misconduct by MPs.

item.title: What is Cubism — and how Braque and Picasso invented it
item.description: Pablo Picasso, a renowned Spanish artist, was born on October 25, 1881. He is known for his extensive body of work, which includes paintings, drawings, engravings, sculptures, and ceramics. Picasso, along with French painter George Braque, invented Cubism, a revolutionary art movement that emerged in 1907 and lasted until 1914. Cubism rejected traditional approaches to art and instead focused on depicting objects from multiple viewpoints. It was not about creating cubes, despite its name. The movement had a significant impact on the art world, inspiring other non-representational art movements like Surrealism. Picasso and Braque drew inspiration from French artist Paul Cézanne, who represented nature using geometric shapes. Cubism also reflected the scientific and technological advancements of the early 20th century, with artists discussing concepts like the fourth dimension. Cubism developed in two phases: analytical cubism, characterized by muted tones and multiple viewpoints, and synthetic cubism, which incorporated real-life objects and brighter colors.

item.title: The story of the Osage Indians’ murders, subject of Scorsese’s Killers of the Flower Moon
item.description: The article discusses the historical events surrounding the Osage Nation, a Native American tribe in Oklahoma, during the 1920s. After oil was discovered on their land, members of the tribe were murdered, leading to the formation of the FBI. The killings exposed the exploitation of Native American resources by white settlers. The upcoming film "Killers of the Flower Moon" tells this story based on David Grann's book. The Osage were forced to give up their territory and move to Kansas before being allocated a reservation in northeastern Oklahoma. The land they moved to had significant oil deposits, which made the Osage wealthy. However, they were not fully in control of their finances due to a system of financial guardians mandated by law. The article focuses on Mollie Burkhart's family, whose members were targeted for their headrights to the oil deposits. Investigations into the murders were initially unsuccessful until an FBI agent named Tom White connected them to William K Hale. Eventually, a law was passed to prevent non-Osage individuals from inheriting headrights. Many believe that the death toll among the Osage was much higher than officially reported.

item.title: NCERT panel suggests replacing ‘India’ with ‘Bharat’: A brief history of the nation’s names
item.description: The 2022 Social Science committee of the National Council of Educational Research and Training (NCERT) in India has suggested that the country should be called "Bharat" in all Social Science textbooks up to Class 12. The committee's chairman, Prof CI Issac, hopes that this change will be implemented in the next academic year, pending approval from the NCERT. The debate about the nation's name has been ongoing, and it gained attention during the G20 Summit when the invitation for the dinner hosted by the President mentioned "The President of Bharat" instead of "President of India." The name "Bharat" has roots in ancient literature and is associated with the land between the sea in the south and the abode of snow in the north. The name "Hindustan" also has historical significance, derived from the Persian cognate form of the Sanskrit word "Sindhu." Over time, the name "India" became more commonly used, especially during British colonial rule. The adoption of "India" as the primary name for the country in the Constitution of India was not without debate, with some arguing for "Bharat" or "Bharatvarsha" instead. Ultimately, the committee adopted the name "India, that is, Bharat."

item.title: Row in Punjab over unemployed asst prof’s suicide: the case of ‘illegal appointments’ under Congress govt
item.description: The alleged suicide of Balwinder Kaur, an unemployed assistant professor in Punjab, has sparked a political controversy. Kaur blamed disputes at home and state education minister Harjot Singh Bains for the stress caused by not getting a job despite being selected as an assistant professor. Kaur was a member of a union of unemployed teachers who have been protesting against the government. Farmer unions and opposition parties have joined their cause, demanding Bains's arrest. The police have booked Kaur's husband and father-in-law for mental cruelty and abetment to suicide. The controversy stems from 1,158 appointments made under the previous government that were later struck down by the High Court as unconstitutional. The recruitment process was challenged in court, with petitioners alleging that it was done hastily for political reasons and violated guidelines. The court ultimately quashed the entire recruitment process. Protesters are demanding justice for Kaur and immediate postings, while the government has challenged the High Court order. The next hearing is scheduled for November 29.

item.title: The benefits that Agniveers get, compared with those of regular soldiers
item.description: The death of a 22-year-old Agniveer deployed on the Siachen glacier has raised concerns about the Agnipath scheme, a contractual recruitment program for the armed forces in India. The scheme, introduced last year, allows recruits to serve for four years with the possibility of joining the services on a regular basis afterward. However, there are criticisms regarding the lack of benefits provided under the scheme, such as gratuity and pensionary benefits. The government introduced the scheme to address the suspension of recruitments due to the Covid-19 pandemic and to bring down defense pension bills. Agniveers receive a monthly remuneration of Rs 30,000-Rs 40,000 and are entitled to risk and hardship allowances. They also contribute to a Seva Nidhi package, which provides financial support upon completion of four years. However, unlike regular soldiers, Agniveers do not receive a pension post-retirement and have limited benefits for their families in case of death or disability. The article highlights the disparities between regular soldiers and Agniveers in terms of salary, insurance coverage, gratuity, and education allowances.

item.title: Why the IDF will struggle to ‘neutralise’ Gaza’s tunnels
item.description: The article discusses the challenge that Israeli forces would face in a ground invasion of Gaza due to the extensive network of tunnels controlled by Hamas. The tunnels, which are approximately 500 km in length and up to 70 m underground, serve various purposes such as smuggling essential items into Gaza and transporting weaponry for Hamas. The tunnels also function as defensive and offensive structures for military operations against Israel. Locating and eliminating these tunnels is a difficult task, as they are often found through human detective work rather than surveillance technology. Additionally, fighting inside the tunnels poses risks for Israeli soldiers, and using bunker-buster bombs could result in collateral damage due to Gaza's dense population. Despite Israel's efforts, it is unlikely that the entire tunnel network would be destroyed.

item.title: The new made-in-India EV charging standard for bikes and scooters: here’s why it matters
item.description: The Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) has approved a new AC and DC combined charging connector standard for light electric vehicles (LEVs) in India. This standard, called ISI7017 (Part 2 / Sec 7): 2023, is the first in the world to combine AC and DC charging for LEVs. It was developed through collaboration among NITI Aayog, the Department of Science and Technology, Ather Energy, and other government and industry stakeholders. The new standard aims to address the issue of multiple charging standards used by different EV makers in India, which makes it difficult for public charging stations to cater to all types of EVs. While the new standard is a step towards interoperability and addressing range anxiety, it does not mandate EV makers to use a uniform standard. In comparison, countries like China have a national standard (GB/T) for EV charging connectors, while Europe uses the Combined Charging System (CCS) as its predominant standard. The US does not have a national standard but some collaboration between EV makers has taken place. Japan uses the CHAdeMO charging standard.

item.title: The new made-in-India EV charging standard for bikes and scooters: here’s why it matters
item.description: The Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) has approved a new charging connector standard for light electric vehicles (LEVs) in India. The standard, called ISI7017 (Part 2 / Sec 7): 2023, is the first in the world to combine alternating current (AC) and direct current (DC) charging for LEVs. This standard was developed through collaboration among NITI Aayog, the Department of Science and Technology, Ather Energy, and other stakeholders. The new standard aims to address the issue of multiple charging standards used by different EV makers in India, which makes it difficult for public charging stations to cater to all types of EVs. However, the standard is not mandatory for EV makers to use, which means that different charging standards may still be used, contributing to range anxiety and hindering the adoption of EVs. In contrast, countries like China, the United States, Europe, and Japan have their own national or regional charging connector standards in place.

item.title: Telangana’s law under scanner: How preventive detention works
item.description: The Telangana government's use of its stringent preventive detention law is being questioned by the Supreme Court ahead of the Assembly polls next month. The law allows for the detention of individuals by the state without trial or conviction, based solely on suspicion. Preventive detention can last up to a year unless extended. Unlike pre-trial detention, preventive detention can be used as a measure even if no crime has been committed. India's constitution allows for preventive detention under Article 22, despite its emphasis on individual liberty. Several states in India also have similar preventive detention laws. The article explains the provisions and safeguards under Article 22 for preventive detention, including the role of advisory boards and the right of the detainee to challenge the detention order in court. However, the scope of judicial review for preventive detention is limited, as the constitution prioritizes the state's subjective satisfaction over fundamental rights. Courts often strike down detention orders on technical grounds.

item.title: Why Mumbai is witnessing more poor air quality days
item.description: The air quality in Mumbai during the winter months is deteriorating, similar to what has been happening in Delhi for the past decade. Previously, Mumbai was considered immune to air pollution due to its coastal location and strong sea breezes that would blow away dust and particles. However, in the last two years, this geographical advantage no longer offers reliable protection. Last year, Mumbai experienced a long period of poor air quality from November to January, with some days being more polluted than Delhi. This trend continued last week when the air quality index (AQI) exceeded 300 in certain parts of the city. Adverse meteorological conditions have contributed to these particularly bad spells, but overall, Mumbai's air quality has been consistently declining. The direction and strength of winds play a crucial role in determining air quality in Mumbai. While the city generates pollutants at a similar rate to Delhi and other urban centers, strong winds usually help sweep away dust particles. However, disruptions in wind patterns can impact air quality, as seen last year when winds changed directions less frequently than usual. This disruption may have been influenced by La Nina conditions in the eastern Pacific Ocean. La Nina is a large-scale phenomenon that affects weather events worldwide. Last year's prolonged and strong La Nina event likely played a role in Mumbai's poor winter air quality. However, La Nina has ended and been replaced by El Nino, whose effects are not yet known. Last week's dip in air quality was caused by different factors, including calmer winds as the monsoon retreated and a temperature gradient between Mumbai and nearby hilly regions that brought dust from construction projects into the city. While unfavorable local weather conditions contribute to poor air quality, the main cause is high levels of pollution exceeding the city's carrying capacity due to increased economic activity, vehicles, construction, consumption, and emissions. Experts warn that Mumbai's air quality has been steadily declining over the past decade and efforts to mitigate the impacts are insufficient.

item.title: Iceland PM joins women’s strike: Why the ‘world’s most gender-equal country’ is protesting inequality
item.description: Women in Iceland, known as the world's most gender-equal country, went on a one-day strike to protest against gender discrimination. Despite Iceland's reputation as an equality paradise, issues such as the gender pay gap and gender-based violence persist. The strike, inspired by a similar action in 1975, saw women refusing all kinds of work, paid and unpaid. Sectors dominated by women, such as healthcare and education, were heavily affected. The Prime Minister, Katrin Jakobsdóttir, also participated in the strike. Activists aim to highlight the connection between underpaid work and gender-based violence, both stemming from the view of women as lesser. The strike aims to challenge societal mindsets and demand urgent action for gender equality in Iceland.

item.title: RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat mentions ‘woke’ in speech: What does the word mean?
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.In his Vijaydashami speech in Nagpur, RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat criticized "cultural Marxists or woke" individuals, referring to them as deceitful and destructive forces in India. He claimed that these individuals, despite claiming lofty goals, have ulterior motives of taking control of media and academia to create confusion and corruption in education, culture, politics, and society. The term "woke" originated in the United States within Black communities, symbolizing awareness and vigilance against violence and social injustice. Over time, it gained prominence through civil rights movements and Black artists' music. Following incidents like the shooting of Michael Brown and George Floyd's death, "woke" became associated with discussions on police brutality and the Black Lives Matter movement. The term has now gone global, with conservative politicians mocking inclusivity as "woke" and using it to criticize causes like gender equality and environmental conservation. However, there is concern among progressive groups that the true activism-heavy history of the term is being diluted as powerful individuals co-opt it for political correctness without meaningful action. Additionally, companies often use the term in advertising campaigns for marketing purposes. While conservatives view "woke" as identity-driven change at odds with liberalism and capitalism, some argue that its message should be stronger, while others question the need for it altogether.

item.title: Bhagwat praises Ambedkar: How the RSS came to embrace the father of India’s constitution
item.description: RSS Sarsanghchalak Mohan Bhagwat has called on his audience to read B.R. Ambedkar's last two speeches in the same way as they read K.B. Hedgewar, the founder of the RSS. This is part of the RSS's practice of praising Ambedkar, particularly since the BJP came to power in 2014. Historically, the RSS criticized Ambedkar and his work, but their position has since evolved. The RSS's initial opposition to Ambedkar was due to his advocacy of reforming Hindu personal laws and his support of the Hindu Code Bill, which aimed to give Hindu women rights. However, since the Meenakshipuram incident in 1981 and the mass conversion of lower-caste Hindus to Islam, the RSS has sought to invoke Ambedkar and Dalits. They have organized gatherings and events to promote Hindu unity and have celebrated Ambedkar's birthday alongside that of Hedgewar. The RSS has also established education centers and sewa vibhags to engage with Dalit communities. In recent years, Bhagwat has emphasized the need for Hindu unity and condemned discrimination. The RSS's shift in position is reflected in the publication of articles praising Ambedkar and featuring his picture on the cover of their journal.

item.title: How the United Nations was born on this day in 1945, and how it has evolved
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The United Nations (UN) was founded on October 24, 1945, after the end of World War II. It was created to maintain world peace and prevent future wars. The UN replaced the League of Nations, which had failed to prevent the outbreak of the Second World War. The idea for the UN was first discussed by US President Franklin D. Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill in 1941, and it was officially established with the signing of the UN Declaration by representatives of 51 nations in 1945. The UN has since grown to include 193 member states and has expanded its scope to address various global issues such as health, environment, and human rights. It has achieved significant milestones, including the creation of the World Health Organization (WHO) in 1948 and the establishment of the International Criminal Court in 2002. However, it has also faced criticism for its failures, such as its inability to prevent genocides in Rwanda and sexual misconduct allegations against its peacekeeping missions. The UN aims to address these challenges and work towards sustainable development goals in the next decade.

item.title: No US House Speaker for over 20 days: Why the Republican party can’t unite
item.description: House Republicans have been struggling to find a replacement for the Speaker after a series of failed attempts. The divisions within the party have made it virtually impossible to unite behind a single candidate. The factions within the party, including the House Freedom Caucus, the Republican Study Committee, the Main Street Caucus, the Mainstream Republican Governance Group, and the Problem Solvers Caucus, each have their own ideologies and interests. Personal vendettas and bad blood among members further complicate the situation. The recent ousting of California Rep. Kevin McCarthy as Speaker was due in part to conflicts with other members, including Rep. Matt Gaetz. Minnesota Rep. Tom Emmer, the current front-runner for the nomination, is facing similar hurdles, with some allies of former President Donald Trump viewing him as disloyal. To become Speaker, a Republican must secure 217 votes, which is a challenging task given the party's current circumstances. The article highlights the difficulty of finding a unifying figure within a deeply divided party.

item.title: US bond yield hits 16-year high of 5 pc: Why is it rising and what does it signal?
item.description: The yield on 10-year government bonds in the US rose to its highest level since July 2007, reaching 5.02%. This increase in bond yields is due to concerns over inflation and the expectation that the US Federal Reserve will keep interest rates high for longer. In India, the yield on 10-year government bonds is already at a high of 7.38%. Factors such as rising crude oil prices, inflation risks, and the US government's borrowing plans have contributed to the rise in bond yields. The increase in yields indicates that the cost of funds in the financial system is rising, leading to higher interest rates. This can have an impact on the overall financial system and put upward pressure on interest rates in the banking system. Rising yields can also lead to a decline in bond prices and impact debt funds and corporate bonds.

item.title: China to build the world’s largest ‘ghost particle’ detector: What are neutrinos and why do they need to be detected?
item.description: China is constructing a large telescope in the western Pacific Ocean to detect neutrinos, also known as "ghost particles". Neutrinos are tiny, chargeless particles that are abundant in the universe but difficult to observe due to their weak interactions with other particles. The new telescope, called "Trident", will be the largest of its kind and will be located in the South China Sea. It is expected to be 10,000 times more sensitive than existing underwater telescopes and will help scientists study the energy and source of neutrinos. Neutrinos are still not fully understood, and their behavior defies established rules of physics. However, understanding them could help solve scientific mysteries such as the origin of cosmic rays. The construction of Trident will bring scientists closer to unraveling the secrets of neutrinos and the origins of our universe.

item.title: The uneven spread of medical colleges, debate over the regulator’s new guidelines
item.description: Nagaland recently opened its first medical college, called the Nagaland Institute of Medical Sciences and Research (NIMSR). The college will have 100 seats available for MBBS students in the upcoming academic session. The government aims to distribute medical colleges evenly across the country. However, a new regulation issued by the National Medical Commission (NMC) in August has put a hold on the establishment of new medical colleges and the expansion of existing ones in states that already have more than 100 medical education seats per million population. This has caused frustration among southern states, as they are now ineligible for additional medical education seats. The NMC argues that these guidelines will reduce regional disparities and ensure quality education for all. They estimate that the country could potentially add 40,000 more MBBS seats if colleges are distributed evenly. The distribution of medical college seats currently varies among states, with Tamil Nadu having the most seats followed by Karnataka and Maharashtra. Meghalaya, Bihar, and Jharkhand have the most acute deficiencies in medical college seats relative to their populations. Despite the government's efforts to increase seats, there is still a shortage of faculty in hospitals even in major cities like Delhi. The NMC's decision will only apply to new colleges or increased seats from the 2024-25 academic year onwards. Many experts agree that there is a need to rationalize the distribution of medical colleges, given the increasing number of private colleges. They believe that the NMC's ratio is necessary to ensure a fair distribution of colleges across the country and to avoid an oversupply of healthcare professionals in certain areas.

item.title: How Ramleela reached Trinidad and became a representation of ‘Indianness’
item.description: Ramleela, a traditional folk theatre performance in India, has made its way to Trinidad through the Indian diaspora. In the early 19th century, Trinidad turned to indentured labor from India after slavery was abolished. The first boatload of indentured Indians arrived in Trinidad in 1845, bringing with them their culture and the Ramcharitmanas, a Hindu text. Ramleela became popular among the Indian community in Trinidad, but its popularity declined as formal education spread and younger generations became less familiar with the Manas. Migration to urban areas and exposure to other cultural influences also contributed to the decline. However, Ramleela has undergone innovation and adaptation to appeal to younger audiences, with increased financial backing leading to higher production values. Despite these changes, the essence of the story and performance remains the same, serving as an anchor for the Indian community in Trinidad and representing their Indianness.

item.title: Hand, Lotus, noodle bowl, charger and more: How are symbols allotted to political parties in India?
item.description: The Supreme Court in India has rejected a petition filed by the ruling Bharat Rashtra Samiti (BRS) party in Telangana, which challenged the allotment of election symbols to two other parties. BRS argued that the symbols of 'road roller' and 'chapatti roller' given to the Yuga Thulasi Party and Alliance of Democratic Reforms Party respectively, were too similar to BRS's symbol of a car and could confuse voters. However, the Supreme Court dismissed the petition, stating that voters were intelligent enough to differentiate between the symbols. The article goes on to explain how symbols are allotted to political parties in India and whether parties have a say in choosing them. The Election Commission of India (ECI) is responsible for the allotment of symbols, which can be either reserved or free. Recognized parties get exclusive symbols, while unregistered parties can choose from free symbols. The ECI publishes lists specifying parties and their symbols through a notification in the Gazette of India. The article also mentions that the late MS Sethi, a former draughtsman for the ECI, sketched many of the symbols used by political parties. Parties are allowed to state their preferences for symbols, but they must not resemble existing symbols or have any religious or communal connotations. When a recognized party splits, the Election Commission decides on the symbol assignment.

item.title: Israel wants civilians to flee northern Gaza: Why that’s not an option for many
item.description: Many people in northern Gaza are unable to flee due to the high cost and lack of safety guarantees. The Israeli military has intensified its bombardment of the area and urged civilians to move south, warning that those who don't may be considered terrorists. However, the danger of Israeli airstrikes on the road has made travel expensive, with drivers charging between $200 and $300 per family. The dire situation in Gaza, with shortages of food, water, and supplies, has led to over half of the population being displaced. The United Nations has condemned the labeling of civilians as accomplices in terrorism and warned that deliberately targeting civilians is a war crime. The Israeli military claims it treats civilians as such and does not target them. Despite the evacuation warnings, airstrikes continue to hit the south, and some families choose to stay in the north due to the lack of familiarity and fear of ending up on the streets. One family's attempt to seek shelter in the south resulted in an airstrike that killed several members.

Automatic variants now make up more than 25% of overall passenger vehicle sales in India. Maruti Suzuki offers automatic transmission variants across almost all its models, with sales highest in Delhi-NCR and Maharashtra. The types of automatic transmissions available in India include AMTs, iMTs, CVTs, DCTs, torque converters, and e-CVTs.
