item.title: ExplainSpeaking | Bidenomics: What is it? Has it worked? What is its significance?
item.description:
Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.In an article by Udit Misra, it is highlighted that the year 2024 will be significant for the global economy due to elections in major economies such as India, Russia, the UK, the EU, and the US. These countries collectively contribute to more than 50% of the global GDP in 2023, with a combined GDP of over $54 trillion. The US election is particularly important, as President Joe Biden is expected to run for re-election, facing a challenge from former President Donald Trump. Bidenomics, the economic policies introduced by President Biden, is a key focus of the article [[SOURCE 1]].
Bidenomics is a term used to refer to the economic policies implemented by the Biden administration. It is a reaction to the economic structure that has been in place since the Reagan presidency in 1981. Reaganomics, which aimed to stimulate economic activity through tax cuts for businesses and reduced government intervention, has been criticized for exacerbating income and wealth inequality. Bidenomics seeks to address these inequalities and promote inclusive growth by investing in infrastructure, reducing trade dependence on countries like China, and raising living standards for the middle and lower-income groups [[SOURCE 1]].
The article discusses two main concerns regarding Bidenomics. First, there is a question of whether it is working effectively. While macro indicators such as GDP growth and unemployment rates show positive trends, there are concerns about income and wealth inequality. Real income growth for the middle 40% of the working population has remained negative for most of the Biden presidency, indicating that the benefits of economic growth may not be reaching everyone [[SOURCE 1]].
The second concern is the ideological disagreement with Bidenomics. Critics argue that the policies implemented, such as providing subsidies to domestic companies, may distort markets and lead to a global subsidy war. This could harm poorer nations and increase inefficiency and corruption within the US. However, proponents of Bidenomics argue that it is necessary to address inequality and counter global rivals like China [[SOURCE 1]].
In conclusion, Bidenomics is an economic approach aimed at reducing inequality and promoting inclusive growth. While it has shown positive macroeconomic indicators, there are concerns about income and wealth inequality and ideological disagreements with the policies implemented. The impact of Bidenomics will continue to be debated as the Biden administration moves forward with its economic agenda [[SOURCE 1]].

item.title: Why Israel attacked Syria’s airports, amid its ongoing war with Hamas
item.description: Israeli warplanes launched strikes on parts of Gaza and two airports in Syria, approximately two weeks after Hamas carried out the largest attack on Israel since its founding. Israel has not explicitly stated its motives for the latest attack but has previously expressed the need to prevent another front opening towards its north. The strikes are believed to be targeting the Lebanon-based, Iran-backed militant group Hezbollah, which has threatened attacks on Israel's north. Hezbollah has historically opposed Israel and received support from Iran. Syria, which has long opposed Israel, has also been involved due to its alliance with Hezbollah. Israel has carried out previous strikes in Syria during the war. Concerns arise from the sizeable force and weaponry of Hezbollah, potentially leading to a ground invasion of Gaza by Israeli forces and spillover effects in West Asia.

item.title: This Quote Means: Tolkien’s ‘not all those who wander are lost’
item.description: The article discusses the meaning and importance of the quote "not all those who wander are lost" from JRR Tolkien's The Lord of the Rings. The quote encourages individuals to deviate from the traditional path in life and explore new experiences. It emphasizes that wandering can lead to personal growth, empathy, and valuable life skills. However, the article also highlights that wandering should have a purpose or goal in order to be productive. The author mentions other literary works, such as Lord Alfred Tennyson's Ulysses, to further illustrate the value of wandering and experiencing different aspects of life. Overall, the article suggests that wandering can bring wonder and magic into one's life and is important for personal development.

item.title: Canada recalls 41 diplomats from India: What is the 1961 Vienna Convention, why it was invoked
item.description: The Canadian government has recalled 41 diplomats and their family members from India due to concerns that their diplomatic immunity could be revoked. This move comes after India sought "parity" with Canada, asking it to reduce its diplomatic staff in the country. The dispute stems from Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's remarks linking the Indian government to the killing of a pro-Khalistan separatist leader in Canada, which India rejected as baseless. The US and UK have backed Canada's diplomats, stating that they should be allowed to resolve differences on the ground. India has rejected Canada's claims and stated that its actions are consistent with the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations.

item.title: Israel-Hamas war: Gaza’s humanitarian situation explained
item.description: Trucks carrying humanitarian aid have entered Gaza for the first time since the October 7 attack by Hamas on Israel, which led to a blockade. The World Health Organization (WHO) stated that the aid supplies, including medicines and medical supplies, will only address a fraction of the escalating health needs in the area. The Gaza Strip, home to 2.2 million people, has been facing shortages of medicine, fuel, and food due to the electricity cut off by Israel. The UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees reported that Gaza is one of the most densely populated areas in the world, with a large population of refugees. The ICRC highlighted the dire situation in hospitals where power shortages are risking the lives of patients. Gaza's unemployment rate is over 45%, and 80% of residents rely on humanitarian assistance. Israel imposed a blockade on Gaza in 2007, severely limiting the movement of people and essential supplies. The Rafa border crossing with Egypt is currently the only route for aid into Gaza.

item.title: What is ‘Visa Shopping’ and why is it being done to enter countries in Europe
item.description: The practice of 'visa shopping' is becoming popular in several Indian states, including Punjab. Visa shopping refers to obtaining visas for countries that individuals may or may not visit during the granted visa period. This allows people to enter their preferred countries, particularly in Europe, even if they have obtained a visa for another European nation. People are also purchasing visas for countries they have no immediate plans to visit in order to increase their chances of obtaining visas for countries of their choice in the future. The Schengen Visa is a popular example of this, as it allows travellers to explore many European countries without the need for separate visas. The Schengen system was established in 1985 and allows people to travel freely between member countries without going through border controls. Many people opt to apply for a Schengen Visa from a country with an easier application process and then use it to travel to their intended destination. While this practice is not illegal if travellers adhere to the norms and guidelines of the visa process, legal concerns arise if a person seeks a visa for a particular country but stays in another or shows that their intentions were not to stay in that country but to only use it as an entry point. The Embassy of Estonia in New Delhi has advised against visa shopping and warned that there may be severe consequences, including refusal of the visa or being offloaded from the plane or returned back home from the EU borders. Repeatedly engaging in visa shopping may also raise suspicion among officials.

item.title: Who are the Bedouin Arabs in the Israeli army?
item.description: The article discusses the role of Bedouin soldiers in Israel's military and their contributions to the country. The Bedouins are a nomadic Muslim Arab people who traditionally lived in the Negev desert in southern Israel. In the past, they provided security and intelligence to early Jewish settlers in Palestine during the Arab-Israeli War. Israel recognized a large number of Bedouins as citizens in the 1950s and built settlements for them in the Negev. Many Bedouin soldiers serve in the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF), particularly in scouting and tracking units. Specialized search and rescue units, mainly comprising Bedouins, were also formed by the IDF. The article mentions that army training is not compulsory for Bedouin youth, but many still volunteer, with a record number of approximately 600 enlisting in 2021. The Bedouin population in Israel currently numbers around 210,000 individuals, with a significant presence in the Negev desert. The Israeli government has launched Operation Negev Shield to integrate Bedouin communities into society through educational programs. The article also highlights the appointment of Israel's first Bedouin ambassador and the presence of Bedouin entrepreneurs in the country's high-tech sector.

item.title: Nawaz Sharif back in Pakistan: What this means for the former PM, his country, and Imran Khan
item.description: Former Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has returned to Pakistan after four years of voluntary exile in London. Sharif, who left Pakistan in 2019 for medical treatment while serving a prison sentence for corruption, landed in Islamabad and will travel to Lahore to hold a gathering of his supporters. His return is seen as a signal that the military is willing to give him another chance and help thwart Imran Khan and his party from coming to power. Sharif's downfall came after he lost support from the military and was accused of corruption. He was disqualified from office and later banned from politics. The military had previously supported Khan but their relationship soured, leading to Khan's ouster as prime minister. Sharif remains popular and the military hopes his return will help defeat Khan's party in the upcoming general elections. However, Sharif must have his corruption-related convictions overturned in order to run for office again.

item.title: Israel missiles hit Gaza’s oldest church: What you need to know about the Church of Saint Porphyrius
item.description: An Israeli airstrike on a building near the Church of Saint Porphyrius in Gaza has caused significant damage to the church. The building, which was affiliated with the church, collapsed in the explosion. Around 500 people had sought refuge at the church compound during the recent hostilities, and at least 16 people were killed and many injured in the airstrike. The Greek Orthodox Patriarchate has condemned the attack as a war crime, stating that targeting churches and their affiliated institutions is unacceptable. The Church of Saint Porphyrius, located in Gaza's Old City, has a long history dating back to the 5th century. It was converted into a mosque after the Islamic conquest but was later reclaimed and rebuilt by Crusaders. Today, it is one of three churches in Gaza and serves as an important institution for the Christian Palestinian community. The church has also provided sanctuary for Muslims during times of conflict. In 2014, during an Israeli bombing campaign, the church's courtyard was used for daily prayers and was also targeted, causing damage to nearby structures.

item.title: As Israel-Hamas conflict gets deadlier, what happens to the India-Europe economic corridor?
item.description:

Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The India-Middle East-Europe Economic Corridor (IMEC) faces significant challenges and complexities in light of the recent fighting in Israel and escalating tensions in the region. The project aims to physically connect a vast stretch of the Eurasian subcontinent through cross-country railway lines and shipping corridors. However, officials from multiple government ministries indicate that the ongoing conflict has made progress on the project even more difficult.
When Prime Minister Modi announced the IMEC alongside US President Joe Biden and Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, there was an acknowledgment of the logistical complexities involved. This includes potential customs checks and clearance for consignments as well as navigating the complex geopolitics of the West Asian region.
The design of the corridor involves traversing diverse nations with different political dynamics, strategic interests, and historical tensions. The US backing was seen as crucial, especially considering the involvement of countries like Israel, Jordan, and Saudi Arabia. However, the recent outbreak of fighting between Hamas and Israel threatens to disrupt these efforts, potentially affecting the Saudi-Israel peace initiative.
The premature announcement of the project without finalized implementation details or funding plans has been criticized as lacking clarity. The use of the land route in the Arabian peninsula could offer logistical advantages by bypassing the congested Suez Canal. Indian officials emphasize the need for close coordination among various departments and ministries involved in the initiative.
The fresh trouble in the West Asia region poses a risk to diplomatic outreach between Israel and Saudi Arabia, as well as other countries like the UAE, Bahrain, and Jordan. Moreover, Turkey has announced its own project as a counter to the IMEC, citing disputed waters along the proposed sea route between Haifa in Israel and Piraeus in Greece.
The IMEC is part of a US-led initiative called the Partnership for Global Infrastructure Investment (PGII), with discussions starting in January 2023. The alignment of the corridor stretches from Western India to Europe via the ports of Piraeus, Haifa, and Dubai. The corridor includes two separate routes: the east corridor connecting India to the Arabian Gulf and the northern corridor connecting the Arabian Gulf to Europe.
The IMEC aims to establish a reliable and cost-effective cross-border ship-to-rail transit network to facilitate the movement of goods and services between India and Europe. It also presents opportunities for laying cables for electricity and digital connectivity, as well as a pipeline for clean hydrogen export. However, the current conflict and geopolitical complexities pose significant challenges to the realization of this ambitious project.

item.title: Affidavit, approver: What Mahua, Hiranandani are talking about
item.description: Darshan Hiranandani, CEO of the Hiranandani Group, has submitted a sworn affidavit to the Ethics Committee of Lok Sabha, making allegations against TMC MP Mahua Moitra and others. Moitra has rejected the contents of the affidavit, stating that it was on a plain piece of paper with no letterhead. Lawyers Shardul Shroff and Pallavi Shroff, who were accused by Hiranandani of providing unverified information to Moitra, pointed out that the statements in the affidavit were not made under oath or verified by an Oath Commissioner. The article also explains the legal definition and purpose of an affidavit, as well as the concept of an "approver" in legal proceedings.

item.title: Azam Khan, wife and son convicted for forgery: What was the case
item.description: Senior Samajwadi Party leader Azam Khan, his wife Tanzeen Fatima, and son Abdullah Azam Khan have been sentenced to seven years in prison for the alleged forgery of Abdullah's birth certificate. This is the fourth case in which Azam has been convicted in the last year. The case was lodged in January 2019 on a complaint from a local BJP leader, and after 11 hearings, the court found the three guilty. The complaint stated that the accused conspired to obtain two birth certificates for personal gain, with one used for a passport and the other for government documents and university affiliation. The prosecution presented 70 documents and 15 witnesses, while the defense argued that there was no motive or criminal intent and that the case was politically motivated. The three have been convicted under various sections of the Indian Penal Code and can file an appeal against the judgement.

item.title: Mahua Moitra and ‘cash for query’ row: How MPs ask questions in Lok Sabha
item.description: Trinamool Congress MP Mahua Moitra has welcomed answering questions from the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) and the Lok Sabha Ethics Committee regarding allegations of "cash for query" against her. This comes after Darshan Hiranandani, CEO of the Hiranandani Group, claimed that Moitra gave him her Parliament login and password to post questions on her behalf. The Lok Sabha generally starts with Question Hour, where MPs can ask ministers questions and hold them accountable. The procedure for asking questions is governed by specific rules, and there are different types of questions that can be asked. Asking questions is an important parliamentary right for MPs to practice legislative control over executive actions and gather information on government activities.

item.title: Israel-Palestine conflict: How international humanitarian law views forced displacement and human shields
item.description: In an article, President Joe Biden accused Hamas of using innocent Palestinians as human shields. Israel has long made this accusation against Hamas, claiming that they hide behind civilians while targeting Israeli civilians. Protests condemning the forced displacement of Palestinians by Israel are ongoing in the Arab world and beyond, as many worry about a refugee influx and permanent Israeli occupation. The use of human shields is considered a war crime under international humanitarian law (IHL), and it is also prohibited to target human shields. The article discusses the complexities of the situation in Gaza due to the population density and highlights that regardless of intent, it would be illegal for Israel to attack civilian homes used for military purposes. Recently, Israel ordered hundreds of thousands of civilians to evacuate from northern Gaza, which could constitute forcible displacement under the statute of the International Criminal Court. The order was criticized by organizations such as the International Committee of the Red Cross and the Norwegian Refugee Council. While warning civilians of military operations is necessary, it is illegal to threaten people to leave. Any displacement of civilians must be temporary and for their benefit, with guarantees of safety and return.

item.title: Canada visa services now available only in Delhi: How will Indian visa seekers, including students, be impacted?
item.description:
Canada has suspended visa and consular services at its consulates in Chandigarh, Mumbai, and Bengaluru, and will now only offer these services at the Canadian High Commission in New Delhi. This decision comes after Canada withdrew 41 diplomats from India, following New Delhi's decision to revoke their diplomatic immunity. The ongoing diplomatic dispute between the two countries was triggered by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegation that India may have been involved in the killing of a Khalistani separatist in Canada.
The expected fallout of this situation is that there will be a significant slowdown in Indian visa applications for Canada. A large portion of these applications come from Indian students who wish to study in Canadian universities. Currently, there are over 319,000 registered Indian students in Canada, making it the second-largest destination for Indian students after the United States. This downsizing of Canada's diplomatic corps and the suspension of visa services in major Indian cities will impact the processing of these applications, potentially causing a backlog.
Indian students make a substantial contribution to the Canadian economy through tuition fees and their spending on living expenses. Tuition fees for international students in Canada are higher than those for domestic students, and it is estimated that Indian students contribute approximately Canadian $10 billion annually to the education sector in the country. Moreover, international students, including Indian students, fill essential jobs in critical sectors of the Canadian economy.
While Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) has stated that it is reducing the number of employees in India from 27 to 5, the visa application centers operated by third-party contractors will not be impacted. These centers process the majority of visa applications outside the country, through IRCC's global network. The remaining staff will focus on urgent cases, visa printing, and working with the visa application centers.
Overall, the slowdown in the visa process is expected to have negative consequences for Indian students and the Canadian economy. The diplomatic dispute between Canada and India has further strained relations and created challenges for those seeking to travel and study between the two countries.

item.title: The colonial — and anti-colonial — roots of Durga Puja
item.description: Hmm, I am not sure. Email support@chatbase.co for more info.The article discusses the history of Durga Puja, a religious festival celebrated in Bengal, India. The origins of modern Durga Puja can be traced back to the nexus between Bengali zamindars (landowners) and merchants, and the East India Company during colonial rule. With Company rule came economic opportunities, leading to the rise of a new class of powerful natives who used Durga Puja as an occasion to display their wealth and socialize with the British elites. By the late 19th century, Durga Puja became a part of the nascent nationalist project, symbolizing the nation and its fight against foreign rule. After Lord Curzon's decision to Partition Bengal in 1905, Durga Pujas became places where collective consciousness and action were forged in the Swadeshi Movement. In the 1920s, public Pujas began to emerge, making the festival accessible to everyone regardless of caste or residence.

item.title: PM Modi flags off RRTS: What is this mass transport system, how it can benefit NCR
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has inaugurated the first leg of India's Regional Rapid Transit System (RRTS), which is the country's first mass rapid system dedicated to regional connectivity. The trains on this first section have the capability to run at speeds up to 180 km/h, which will eventually reduce the journey time between Delhi and Meerut to less than an hour. The RRTS is an integrated mass transit network aimed at achieving balanced and sustainable urban development by providing better connectivity and access across the National Capital Region (NCR). The idea for this network originated from a study commissioned by the Indian Railways in 1998-99, which identified the possibility of connecting various locations in the NCR through fast commuter trains. The proposal was later re-examined in 2006 with the extension of the Delhi Metro lines to towns in the NCR. The National Capital Region Transport Corporation (NCRTC) was established to implement the RRTS project, which includes eight corridors to connect different towns in the NCR. The RRTS, also known as Namo Bharat, aims to unlock the full potential of the NCR by enhancing multi-modal connectivity and reducing congestion on roads, highways, metro, and railway networks. Additionally, the project is expected to boost employment and stimulate economic activity in the region. The RRTS trains will run faster than metro trains, operating at speeds up to 180 km/h, compared to the maximum speed of 100-120 km/h for Delhi Metro trains. The Phase I development includes three corridors: Delhi-Ghaziabad-Meerut (82 km), Delhi-Gurugram-SNB-Alwar (164 km), and Delhi-Panipat (103 km). The project plans to develop five more corridors in the future. The Sarai Kale Khan station in Delhi will serve as the central hub for all three Phase I corridors. The priority section of the Delhi-Ghaziabad-Meerut corridor, a 17 km stretch with five stations, has been inaugurated, and the entire corridor is scheduled to be operational by 2025.

item.title: What is the first test on Gaganyaan journey, to be held on Saturday
item.description: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is set to conduct the Flight Test Vehicle Abort Mission-1 (TV-D1) on Saturday, as part of its preparations for launching an Indian astronaut into space. The TV-D1 mission will test the Crew Escape System of the Gaganyaan project, which allows the crew to leave the spacecraft in an emergency. The rocket will reach an altitude of almost 17 km before triggering an abort signal, leading to the separation of the crew module and its descent using a parachute. The test mission will last 532 seconds and will demonstrate the new Test Vehicle and a basic version of the crew module. ISRO has developed a low-cost Test Vehicle specifically for these tests, using existing liquid propulsion technology. The Gaganyaan human space flight programme has a budget of around Rs 9,000 crore ($1.2 billion).

item.title: Vladimir Putin seen with ‘nuclear briefcase’ in China: Its history, what it contains
item.description: During Russian President Vladimir Putin's recent visit to China, he was seen with officers carrying the "nuclear briefcase." This briefcase is part of a system for authorizing the launch of nuclear strikes. It is used to convey orders for a nuclear strike to the rocket forces of the country. The briefcases are also carried by the defense minister and the chief of general staff, who coordinate with the president in case of a potential order to strike. The first known instance of a nuclear briefcase being used was in 1995 during a crisis. The briefcases were developed during the Cold War to cut down reaction time in the event of a sudden attack. The American president also has a similar briefcase, officially called the presidential emergency satchel or the "football," which contains information on retaliatory options and authentication codes to authorize a nuclear attack. Other countries have similar systems as well. There have been instances of misplaced or lost codes in the past.

item.title: Row over Jagannath temple’s treasure room: Why has it not been unlocked in 38 years, why demands to open now
item.description: The demand to open the Ratna Bhandar (treasure room) of the Puri Jagannath Temple in Odisha is growing as assembly and general elections approach. The treasure room has not been unlocked for 30 years. The BJP and Congress have both raised the issue and demanded its opening. The Ratna Bhandar stores precious ornaments given by devotees and kings over centuries. The outer chamber is regularly opened for rituals, but the inner chamber has not been opened in 38 years. The demand to open the Ratna Bhandar has increased due to concerns about cracks in its walls that could endanger the precious ornaments. The last inventory of the treasure room was done in 1978, and efforts to open it in 2018 were unsuccessful due to missing keys. A judicial inquiry was ordered to investigate the loss of the keys. The issue resurfaced when the ASI sought permission to inspect the inner chamber in 2022. Eminent individuals and opposition parties have demanded the opening of the treasure room, leading to the temple managing committee recommending its opening during the annual rath yatra in 2024. The Orissa HC directed the government to form a high-level committee to supervise the inventory-making of the valuables but declined to interfere in the inventory and repair plans.

item.title: Who are the Palestinians?
item.description: The article discusses the oversimplification of the Palestinian identity in media coverage of the Israel-Palestine conflict. It highlights that the emphasis is often placed on Palestinians being Muslims who are in conflict with Jewish Israelis, which fails to acknowledge the rich and complex history of the Palestinians. The term "Palestine" originated in ancient Greece and referred to the coastal land between Phoenicia and Egypt. The region underwent Islamisation and saw the emergence of various overlapping identities. After the defeat of the Ottomans in World War I, Palestine was divided among the British and the French. The Palestinian national charter of 1968 emphasized the Palestinians' Arab identity but did not define Palestine in religious terms. The majority of Palestinians today are Sunni Muslims, but there is also a Jewish minority in Palestinian areas. Palestinian Christians make up a small percentage of the population.

item.title: Suspected Banksy artwork appears in London: The artist’s long connection with Palestine
item.description:
A new Banksy mural has appeared near the Edgware Road Underground Station in London. The artwork, which depicts robotic arms being pulled by three individuals, bears the words "another world is possible." While Banksy has not claimed ownership of the piece, it has attracted a large number of visitors. Interpretations of the artwork vary, with some viewing it as a warning against the dangers of artificial intelligence and others seeing it as a commentary on the ongoing Israel-Palestine conflict.
Banksy has a history of working in Palestine since the early 2000s, with his artworks being spotted in the region, including on the West Bank wall. He also owns a hotel next to the separation wall in Bethlehem called the Walled Off Hotel. The hotel features rooms with artwork by Banksy and other artists, a gallery showcasing Palestinian artworks, and a museum with audio-visual presentations about the region's history.
One of Banksy's most notable statements on the Israel-Palestine conflict is a video he released in 2015, sarcastically promoting tourism in Gaza. The video highlights the devastation in Gaza and the restrictions faced by its residents, juxtaposed with the Israeli military presence. Banksy also references the destruction caused by the 2014 military operation and the network of illegal tunnels. The video concludes with a quote spray-painted on a wall, emphasizing the importance of not remaining neutral in conflicts between the powerful and the powerless.
Banksy's artworks in the region include the famous "Love is in the Air" mural in Jerusalem, which depicts a man throwing a bouquet of flowers instead of a weapon, symbolizing peace. He has also created murals featuring children interacting with Israeli soldiers and commenting on the Israeli occupation. One of his well-known projects in Palestine is a series of large murals painted on the segregation wall in 2005, including images of children playing on a sandcastle and a variation of Banksy's "Girl with Balloon" painting.
Overall, Banksy's artworks in Palestine and his recent mural in London continue his exploration of political and social issues, provoking thought and sparking conversations about topics such as artificial intelligence and the Israel-Palestine conflict.

item.title: Severe drought grips the Amazon rainforest: The impact, cause and grim future
item.description: The Amazon rainforest is experiencing a severe drought, causing rivers to dry up and leaving Indigenous communities without water, food, or medicine. The Rio Negro, one of the largest rivers in the world, has reached a record low level. The drought has also led to dead fish and river dolphins contaminating the water supply, leaving residents with limited access to clean water. The lack of water has affected a major hydropower dam and stranded tens of thousands of people in remote villages. The dry conditions have also increased the risk of wildfires, with the Amazonas state experiencing a high number of blazes this month. The drought is attributed to the combined effects of El Nino and high sea surface temperatures. Studies suggest that with rising global temperatures, the Amazon will experience more frequent and longer droughts, potentially leading to irreversible damage and releasing stored carbon into the atmosphere. Experts emphasize the need to curb deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions to protect the Amazon and its vital role in global ecosystems.

item.title: Scriptures may be copyright-free, but adaptations are protected: What HC has said
item.description: The Delhi High Court has ruled that there is "large-scale infringement" of copyrighted works by the Bhaktivedanta Book Trust on the internet. The trust, which publishes books and commentaries on Indian religious philosophy, has been granted permission to approach tech companies Google and Meta (owners of YouTube and Instagram) with takedown orders against those reproducing copyrighted works on the Srimad Bhagavad Gita. The court found that while religious scriptures are in the public domain, copyright protection applies to original parts of literary works that explain or interpret these scriptures. The court also noted that Srila Prabhupada, the founder of the trust, had handed over copyrights to be administered by the trust, making unauthorized reproduction a violation.

North Korea has managed to bypass international sanctions through alliances with Russia and China. The South Korean Foreign Ministry stated that any weapons exchanges between North Korea and Russia are a clear violation of United Nations Security Council resolutions and a threat to peace and stability on the Korean Peninsula. item.title: Israel using white phosphorus in Gaza? 5 things about the controversial weapon
item.description: Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch have accused the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) of using white phosphorus munitions in Gaza and Lebanon, in violation of International Humanitarian Law (IHL). The organizations claim that Israel's use of these munitions in densely populated areas poses long-term risks to civilians. White phosphorus is a pyrophoric substance that ignites when exposed to oxygen, producing thick smoke and intense heat. It is primarily used as a smokescreen to hide troop movement and can also be used as an incendiary weapon. Exposure to white phosphorus can cause severe burns, respiratory damage, and harm to internal organs. The use of white phosphorus munitions is regulated under the Convention on Conventional Weapons (CCW), specifically Protocol III, but there are loopholes in the regulations. Efforts have been made to strengthen the CCW to address these loopholes.

item.title: What DA hike means for govt employees, the exchequer
item.description: The Union Cabinet has approved a 4 percentage point increase in Dearness Allowance (DA) and Dearness Relief for central government employees and pensioners, bringing it to 46% from 42%. The hike will be effective from July 1st and is intended to benefit government employees and pensioners during the festive season. The hike will cost the exchequer Rs 12,857 crore per year. Approximately 48.67 lakh central government employees and 67.95 lakh pensioners will benefit from this increase. This hike follows the recommendations of the 7th Central Pay Commission. The DA for employees and pensioners is estimated based on the Consumer Price Index for Industrial Workers (CPI-IW), released monthly by the Labour Bureau. The last revision in DA was done on March 24, 2023, and was effective from January 1, 2023. In addition, the government has announced the grant of non-productivity linked bonus (ad-hoc bonus) for eligible employees for the year 2022-23. The ad-hoc bonus has been approved for certain categories of employees, including paramilitary forces, and the calculation ceiling for payment has been set at Rs 7,000.

item.title: Why a Supreme Court order on telcos’ licence fee tax has the industry worried

This decision could lead to a tax liability of around $1 billion for telecom companies like Bharti Airtel and Vodafone Idea in the current fiscal year. The Court's decision means that telecom companies will need to deduct a portion of the total fee over each year for tax purposes, rather than deducting the entire expenditure at once. This change in accounting is expected to result in lower cash flow for telecom companies. It is unclear whether the change will be applied retrospectively, and income tax authorities are expected to demand any shortfall in tax payment for the prior period, along with penalties. Telecom companies are likely to file a review petition, which could delay the actual tax liability. Bharti Airtel is currently examining the order and its impact to determine the next course of action.

item.title: Supreme Court’s marriage equality judgment unpacked: Two views on four key issues
item.description:
A five-judge Constitution Bench of the Supreme Court, led by Chief Justice of India (CJI) D Y Chandrachud, has declined to grant legal status to same-sex marriages. The majority opinion, held by three judges, stated that the issue should be addressed by the legislature rather than the judiciary. While the CJI and Justice Sanjay Kishan Kaul recognized civil unions for queer couples, they were in the minority. The judges provided their views on four key questions raised during the case.
Regarding the argument that there exists a fundamental right to marry a person of one's own choice under the Constitution, the minority view disagreed. They stated that marriage may have gained significance because of state regulation, rather than being inherently fundamental. The majority opinion agreed with this perspective, emphasizing that personal preference and social status are important aspects of marriage. They also highlighted that the US courts' reasoning for declaring the right to marry a fundamental right may not be applicable.
The court considered a gender-neutral interpretation of the legislation governing civil marriages, where the state sanctions the marriage instead of religion. However, the minority view warned against entering the domain of the legislature, while the majority view stated that the legislation is intended only for heterosexual couples belonging to different faiths.
The petitioners also argued against discriminatory adoption guidelines set by the Central Adoption Resource Authority (CARA). The minority view found certain CARA regulations to be precluding unmarried couples from adopting without sufficient justification. They emphasized that good or bad parenting should not be assumed based on individuals' sexuality. The majority view agreed with the discriminatory impact on queer couples but stated that legislative changes are necessary to address this issue.
Regarding the recognition of civil unions for queer couples, the minority view located the right to form intimate associations within the fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression. They suggested that a committee would determine the rights available to queer couples in unions. In contrast, the majority view disagreed with prescribing civil unions as a choice for queer couples, suggesting that the state should facilitate this choice if the community desires it.
Overall, the Supreme Court's Constitution Bench refused to grant legal status to same-sex marriages, emphasizing that the issue falls within the domain of the legislature rather than the judiciary. The judges provided differing opinions on various aspects related to fundamental rights, legislation interpretation, adoption guidelines, and civil unions for queer couples.

item.title: Why Supreme Court’s same-sex marriage verdict opens no doors for queer people
item.description:
In November 2022, two same-sex couples brought a case to the Supreme Court of India, arguing that their inability to marry under Indian family law violated their fundamental rights. After a 10-day hearing, the court reserved its judgment and delivered its final verdict on October 17, 2023.
The court, with a majority of three judges, addressed key questions in their separate opinions. The main issue was whether same-sex couples have the right to marry under the Indian Constitution and if the prevention of such marriages is discriminatory. The court unanimously answered both questions in the negative.
The court held that marriage is an institution established by law, and same-sex couples do not have the right to participate in it unless the law permits them to do so. The court found that the Special Marriage Act, which permits marriages only between a man and a woman, was constitutional.
The court also rejected the idea of allowing queer couples to enter into a civil union, stating that only an elected legislature has the authority to make such changes. The court acknowledged the complexity of aligning legal frameworks based on heterosexual unions with the right of queer individuals to marry.
Regarding adoption, since same-sex couples cannot legally marry in India, they cannot adopt as a couple. However, a single person within a same-sex couple could adopt a child. The court shifted the burden to the executive branch, encouraging it to reconsider adoption laws in line with the best interests of children.
In summary, the court's judgment did not recognize queer marriages or civil unions. It affirmed the right of queer individuals to choose a partner, even if it does not amount to a marriage or union. The court acknowledged the exclusion of the queer community from family laws but shifted the responsibility to the legislature to address these issues. The court directed the government to set up a committee to examine potential amendments to make the benefits of marriage available to same-sex couples.
The judgment represents a setback for the queer community, and the authors suggest that the legislature should take the lead in re-evaluating and improving Indian family law to be more inclusive and non-discriminatory.

The first written reference of the game being played in the Netherlands dates back to 1845. However, cricket in the Netherlands developed differently from British colonies, with different clubs following their own rules and ideas of the game. This lack of standardization led to embarrassing losses for the Dutch team against proper English sides. In 1884, the Nederlandsche Cricket Board (NCB) was founded to ensure proper administration of the game, making it the second international cricket association in the world after MCC. World War I brought an influx of talent to Dutch leagues, and cricket continued to grow in popularity throughout the 1930s. Despite World War II, cricket did not stop being played in the Netherlands and was seen as a demonstration of defiance against Nazi occupation. The professionalization of Dutch football in 1954 made it more accessible than cricket, leading to its decline as a popular sport. Additionally, the exclusionary policies of the International Cricket Council (ICC), which only granted Test status to England, Australia, and South Africa, further hindered the development of cricket in the Netherlands. If ICC had been more inclusive, Netherlands could have enjoyed regular international matches and seen an increase in standards and performances.

item.title: PMK says abolish All India Quota: The problem of vacant MBBS seats in Tamil Nadu

The issue stems from the National Medical Commission's (NMC) policy on student admissions. Previously, the central government conducted two counseling rounds, and unfilled seats were given to the states. However, after increasing counseling rounds to four, now unfilled seats go to waste. This has resulted in vacancies in top medical colleges, causing missed opportunities and financial losses. The situation appears to have worsened from the previous year. Despite efforts from the Medical Counselling Committee (MCC) and the state selection committee, seats remain empty. Tamil Nadu contributes over 800 seats to the All India quota, and there are calls to appeal to the Supreme Court to prevent these high-demand seats from going unclaimed. Experts argue that the flawed admission policy by the central government is at the crux of the problem. The government announced in 2021 that it would no longer return any seat surrendered by state governments. While private medical colleges with high fees can admit students until the deadline, state-run colleges with lower fees are left with vacancies. PMK leader Ramadoss suggests scrapping the All India quota, as each state now has its own medical institutions.

item.title: Before SC, question of law in Muslim women’s right to divorce
item.description: The Supreme Court will review a ruling by the Kerala High Court that affirmed a Muslim woman's right to pronounce extrajudicial divorce through "khula." Khula is the right of a Muslim woman to unilaterally divorce her husband, similar to talaq for Muslim men. Scholars differ on whether the husband's consent is necessary for khula. Other forms of extrajudicial divorce available to Muslim women include talaq-e-tafwiz (contract-based divorce), mubara'at (separation by mutual consent), and faskh (divorce through court intervention). The 1939 Dissolution of Muslim Marriages Act clarified and consolidated the provisions of extrajudicial divorce for Muslim women, including the faskh route. The Kerala HC ruled in 2021 that Muslim women retain their right to extrajudicial divorce under the 1939 Act.

item.title: Why Putin has compared Israel’s actions in Gaza to the Nazi siege of Leningrad
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin recently warned Israel against besieging Gaza in a manner reminiscent of Nazi Germany's siege of Leningrad. Operation Barbarossa, Hitler's attack on the Soviet Union, included the devastating siege of Leningrad. The city was strategically and symbolically important to the Soviets, who mobilized citizens and soldiers to defend it. The siege lasted for 872 days and involved constant shelling, famine, and harsh weather conditions. Approximately 650,000 residents of Leningrad died in 1942 alone, with around 100,000 perishing each month during the peak winter. Ultimately, 1.5 million people lost their lives during the siege, with an additional 500,000 dying during evacuation attempts. The tragedy of Leningrad was on a scale greater than the combined casualties of the United States and Britain in the entire war. German forces targeted civilians by cutting off supplies, leading to widespread starvation. Some desperate individuals even resorted to cannibalism. Putin's personal connection to the siege, as his brother died during that time, likely contributes to his invocation of this historical event. His mother also experienced near-starvation during the siege.

item.title: What the 2023 Nobel Economics Prize winner says on women’s aspirations, role in workforce and pay gap
item.description:
Claudia Goldin, an economist and winner of the Nobel Prize in economics, explores the history of college-educated women in the United States in her book "Career & Family: Women’s Century-Long Journey Toward Equity." She examines how women's aspirations and circumstances have changed over time, highlighting the ongoing problem of women feeling short-changed in their careers compared to their husbands and male colleagues. Goldin attributes this problem to sex discrimination, gender bias, and the glass ceiling. However, she suggests that even if these issues were to disappear, the problem would still persist due to the underlying system at play.
The book categorizes women who graduated from college into five groups ranging from the 1900s to the 1990s. Goldin explores how their aspirations shifted over time, from having to choose between a career and family, to sacrificing one for the other, to ultimately aspiring for both equally. She attributes these shifts to factors such as laws that initially prohibited women and married women from working, which later changed with increased job demand after the Great Depression and the "baby boom" era following World War II.
The introduction of the birth control pill in 1960 allowed women to delay childbirth and marriage, leading to greater enrollment in post-graduate courses and aspirations for long-term careers rather than just jobs. The feminist movement of the 1960s and 1970s also played a role in increasing women's participation in the workforce, contributing significantly to economic growth.
Goldin emphasizes the tension between work and caregiving responsibilities as a major challenge faced by women today. This challenge impacts women's career goals and contributes to the gender pay gap. While previous explanations attributed the pay gap to differences in fields of study and occupational choices, Goldin argues that it expands as men and women age, get married, and have children.
The root of the problem, according to Goldin, is the prevalence of "greedy work," referring to careers that demand extensive time and attention, such as doctors, lawyers, and senior corporate executives. Greedy jobs heavily reward individuals who are available at all times, creating an imbalance between work and family life. Goldin asserts that addressing this issue requires changing the existing work and care structures, which she considers relics of a time when men were the only ones who could have both careers and families.
One part of the solution involves making rewarding, well-paying work more flexible in terms of hours and allowing for time-offs. Goldin cites fields like veterinary medicine in the US as examples of how this flexibility has been implemented to some extent. Remote work, which became more prevalent during the pandemic, also provides a potential solution.
Men play a crucial role in achieving gender equality at work and in caregiving. Goldin emphasizes the importance of men supporting their male colleagues on parental leave, advocating for public policies that subsidize childcare, and pressuring their firms to adopt more flexible practices. Ultimately, Goldin calls for a reimagination of work and care to allow both men and women to have fulfilling careers and family lives.

The conflict falls under an international system of justice that has evolved since World War II. The rules governing this conflict are based on the internationally accepted principles of armed conflict, as outlined in the 1949 Geneva Conventions. These conventions have been ratified by all UN member states and have been supplemented by rulings from international war crimes tribunals. These rules, collectively known as the "law of armed conflict" or "international humanitarian law," apply to government forces, organized armed groups, and Hamas militants.
If alleged perpetrators of atrocities in Israel, including Palestinians, or alleged crimes in the occupied Palestinian territories are not brought to justice locally, the International Criminal Court (ICC) in The Hague is the only international legal body that can bring charges. While domestic courts can exercise universal jurisdiction in war crimes cases, its scope is limited. The ICC derives its legal authority from the Rome Statute and can investigate alleged crimes on the territories of its member states or committed by their nationals when domestic authorities are "unwilling or unable" to do so. The ICC's Office of the Prosecutor has confirmed that its mandate applies to potential crimes committed in the current conflict and is currently collecting information.
The ICC, established in 2002, is the world's permanent war crimes tribunal. It has jurisdiction over war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide in its 123 member states or committed by their nationals. However, major powers such as China, the United States, Russia, India, and Egypt are not members. While the ICC recognizes Palestine as a member state, Israel rejects the court's jurisdiction and does not engage with it formally. Due to budget and staff constraints, ICC prosecutors are already investigating 17 cases in different countries, and the budget for investigations in the Palestinian territories for 2023 is just under a million euros ($1.06 million).
The ICC has been conducting an ongoing investigation into allegations of war crimes and crimes against humanity in the occupied Palestinian territories since 2021 but has not yet issued any arrest warrants. Prosecutors have stated that there is a reasonable basis to believe that violations have been committed by all sides, including Israeli troops, Hamas militants, and other armed Palestinian groups.
Acts that could potentially violate war crimes law include the deliberate targeting of civilians, indiscriminate rocket attacks, taking civilians as hostages by Palestinian armed groups, and the Israeli counter-strikes in Gaza resulting in the deaths of hundreds of Palestinians. The deliberate killings of civilians, hostage-taking, and collective punishment are deemed heinous crimes by human rights organizations, with no justification. Violations such as the taking of hostages, murder, and torture are explicitly prohibited under the Geneva Conventions. Israel's response to the conflict could also be subject to a war crimes investigation, particularly concerning the announcement of a tightened blockade and the possibility of a ground invasion to destroy Hamas.
US President Joe Biden has stated that Israel has the right and duty to respond but emphasized the importance of acting according to the rule of law. A siege can be considered a war crime if it targets civilians instead of being a legitimate means to undermine Hamas' military capabilities or if it is deemed disproportionate. Under international law, attacks on military objectives must be proportional and should not lead to excessive loss of civilian life or damage to civilian objects compared to the expected military advantage. A defense lawyer at the ICC highlighted the gruesome killings by Hamas militants, such as the attack on a dance rave and civilians in kibbutz communities near the Gaza border, as potential focuses for a war crimes case.

Let's take a quick look at each of them and their roles in the Israel-Palestine conflict.
Fatah, meaning "to conquer," was formed in the late 1950s in Kuwait. It was established by key figures like Yasser Arafat and Mahmoud Abbas with the objective of armed struggle against Israel to liberate Palestine. Fatah's military operations began in 1965 and were carried out from Jordan and Lebanon. In 1968, Fatah became part of the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO), which aimed to achieve statehood for Palestine through armed resistance. However, Fatah later transformed its approach and started negotiating with Israel. In the 1990s, Fatah-led PLO renounced armed resistance and signed the Oslo Accords, which established the Palestinian National Authority (PNA) or Palestinian Authority (PA) as an interim self-governing body leading to an independent Palestinian state. Currently, Fatah heads the PA, governing about 40% of the occupied West Bank.
Hamas, founded in the late 1980s, is another major political party in Palestine known for its ongoing armed struggle against Israel. Like Fatah, Hamas aims to establish a Palestinian state on the borders of 1967. However, unlike Fatah, Hamas has not recognized the statehood of Israel. Since 2006, Hamas has been ruling the Gaza Strip.
The Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ) is the second-largest militant group in Palestine, aiming to destroy Israel and establish an Islamic Palestinian state through force. It was established in 1981 by members of Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood and is believed to receive financial support from Iran. Though Hamas and PIJ are allies, they have separate identities and some differences. PIJ has mainly focused on armed struggle but also participated in student politics and legislative elections.
The Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) was conceived in 1964 with the goal of liberating Palestine through armed struggle. It is a coalition of smaller Arab groups, with Fatah being the dominant one. PLO was recognized by the Arab League and the United Nations as the "sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people." In the early 1990s, PLO gave up armed struggle and recognized the statehood of Israel, which led to the rise of Hamas.
The Palestinian Authority (PA) was founded in 1994 as an interim body to govern parts of Gaza and the West Bank. It functions as an agency of the PLO and is led by a directly-elected president, currently Mahmoud Abbas. In 2006, Hamas won the legislative elections and took control of the Gaza Strip, while the PA continued to govern parts of the West Bank.
These various groups and organizations play significant roles in the complex Israel-Palestine conflict, each with its own history, objectives, and approach.

item.title: What was the Yom Kippur war, and why is the Hamas attack on Israel being compared to it
item.description:
The recent surprise attack by Hamas on Israel has brought back memories of the Yom Kippur War, which started 50 years ago. This current conflict is being compared to the Yom Kippur War for a couple of reasons. Firstly, it has been the deadliest attack on Israel since the Yom Kippur War in 1973. Hamas gunmen carried out a rampage in Israeli towns, killing at least 400 Israelis and kidnapping civilians. In retaliation, Israeli strikes have killed at least 313 Palestinians. In the Yom Kippur War, over 2,500 Israeli soldiers were killed.
The second similarity is the criticism within Israel for being unprepared. The attack on Saturday came as a surprise, despite Israel's advanced intelligence and interception systems. This is similar to the Yom Kippur War, where Israel was also caught off guard due to many soldiers being on leave for Yom Kippur, the holiest day in Judaism.
The Yom Kippur War, also known as the October War or the Ramadan War, was fought between Israel, Egypt, and Syria from October 6 to 25, 1973. It was the fourth Arab-Israeli war, following conflicts in 1949, 1956, and 1967. After Israel's decisive victory in the six-day war of 1967, it acquired territories from its neighbors, including the Golan Heights from Syria and the Sinai Peninsula from Egypt.
Six years later, Egypt and Syria coordinated an attack on Israel. Israel was initially caught off guard and took time to mobilize its soldiers who were on leave for Yom Kippur. While both Syria and Egypt made some gains initially, Israel eventually halted their advances and launched counterstrikes. The intervention of the US and the Soviet Union further escalated tensions between the superpowers. A lasting ceasefire was finally reached on October 25, weakening Israel's previously perceived invincibility.
Despite Israel's ability to beat back both attackers, the Yom Kippur War is still seen as a game-changer. Israel's scramble to rally troops initially and the heavy casualties it suffered showed that it could be vulnerable in battle. Prime Minister Golda Meir and her cabinet resigned six months after the war. Many analysts believe that Egypt's strategy behind launching the attack was to bruise Israel enough to bring it to the negotiating table.
Following the war, a peace process was initiated, leading to the 1978 Camp David Accords in which Israel returned the Sinai Peninsula to Egypt. This marked the first instance of an Arab country recognizing Israel as a state. However, for Syria, the war had no positive outcomes as Israel continued to occupy the strategically important Golan Heights.

The central bank did not specify a timeline for this proposal, causing the yield on benchmark 10-year government bonds to rise by 12 basis points to 7.34%. This unexpected move led to speculation of an OMO being implemented soon, which would tighten liquidity in the system. The surprise element stemmed from the absence of a specific calendar for these operations, leaving market participants on edge as OMOs could potentially be announced at any time.
The market was not anticipating such a measure by the RBI to withdraw excess liquidity, adding a hawkish tone to the monetary policy. Liquidity is expected to tighten further due to cash withdrawals during the upcoming festival season. RBI Governor Shaktikanta Das mentioned that OMO sales may be considered to manage liquidity, but the timing and quantity of such operations will depend on evolving liquidity conditions.
OMOs are used by the RBI to adjust rupee liquidity conditions in the market on a lasting basis. If there is excess liquidity, the central bank sells government securities to remove rupee liquidity. Conversely, when liquidity conditions are tight, the RBI purchases securities to release liquidity into the market. OMOs are employed as a tool to control inflation and money supply. However, when liquidity is sucked out, it can lead to higher bond yields, as the RBI introduces more government securities into the market, causing bond buyers to demand higher interest rates on these securities.
The RBI's emphasis on active liquidity management during the post-policy press conference indicates its inclination towards tighter liquidity conditions in the future. This approach is driven by concerns about inflation risks and financial stability, aligning with the central bank's objective of keeping inflation at 4%. The RBI aims to achieve this target through liquidity management, particularly during the October-May period when cash withdrawals are high due to festive and wedding seasons.
The current liquidity position is such that the RBI may opt for OMO sales auctions of government securities to absorb any excess liquidity. In September, the RBI conducted OMO sales in the secondary market, resulting in net sales amounting to Rs 6,200 crore. Despite the gradual withdrawal of the incremental cash reserve ratio (i-CRR) implemented in the August Monetary Policy Committee meeting, systemic liquidity remained in deficit due to tax outflows and GST payments. The government's cash balance with the RBI is estimated at around Rs 2.7 lakh crore, and an increase in government spending and the withdrawal of i-CRR could boost systemic liquidity. item.title: How China invaded Tibet and annexed it
item.description: This article discusses the Chinese invasion of Tibet in 1950 and its long-lasting impact. It emphasizes how the invasion was initially unknown to most Tibetans due to the remote location of the region and the slow spread of news. The Chinese Communist Party had both ideological and pragmatic motivations for annexing Tibet, wanting to secure the border and access its natural resources while also seeing it as a feudal-theocracy in need of liberation. However, Tibet had historically existed independently, with its own culture, language, and religion. Tense negotiations took place between Lhasa and Beijing, but China steadily built up forces at Tibet's border to exert pressure. The People's Liberation Army invaded Tibet in October 1950, capturing the town of Chamdo and forcing the Tibetan garrison to surrender. China then sent the defeated governor of Chamdo to Lhasa to propose the seventeen point agreement to the Dalai Lama. Under duress, Tibetan plenipotentiaries signed the agreement in May 1951, subordinating Tibet to China while promising non-interference in domestic affairs, culture, and religion. However, China soon violated the agreement and introduced communist reforms in Tibet, eroding its autonomy and imposing cultural and economic changes. Massive resistance grew in Tibet by 1954, and in 1959, a revolt erupted in Lhasa amid fears that the CCP might arrest the Dalai Lama. Chinese reprisals were brutal, resulting in the deaths of thousands and the destruction of monasteries. The Dalai Lama fled to India, repudiated the seventeen point agreement, and declared himself as Tibet's legitimate representative. Since then, China has maintained absolute control over Tibet, suppressing dissent, placing its own people in religious positions, and encouraging Han Chinese immigration, which has affected Tibet's demographics and culture.

item.title: Nobel Prize in Literature: In Norwegian laureate Jon Fosse’s ‘slow prose’, shades of Ibsen and Derrida
item.description: Norwegian playwright, poet, novelist, essayist, and translator Jon Fosse has won the Nobel Prize in Literature for his focus on the subterranean that connects personal experiences with universal themes. Fosse's work, which includes innovative plays, novels, poetry collections, essays, children's books, and translations, gives voice to the unsayable. While he is known for his plays, Fosse has also gained recognition for his prose. In his acceptance statement, Fosse expressed gratitude and a sense of overwhelm, seeing the award as a recognition of literature that aims to be literature above all else. Fosse's literary career began with the novel "Red Black" in 1983, and he has since written several notable plays and novels. His work is often compared to that of Henrik Ibsen and Jacques Derrida for its modernist concerns and ability to tap into the unspoken.

item.title: Nobel Prize for Literature 2023: Meet the winner, the Norwegian author Jon Fosse
item.description: Norwegian author Jon Olav Fosse has been awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature 2023 for his innovative plays and prose that give voice to the unsayable. Fosse's work presents everyday situations that are relatable and expresses powerful human emotions of anxiety and powerlessness in simple terms. He is regarded as a major innovator in contemporary theatre for his ability to evoke man's loss of orientation and provide access to a deeper experience close to divinity. Fosse writes in Norwegian Nynorsk, the least common version of Norwegian, and sees the award as recognition for this language and the movement promoting it. He started writing novels before switching to plays and has become one of Norway's most-performed dramatists. His works have been translated into over 40 languages, and he has written around 40 plays along with novels, short stories, children's books, poetry, and essays. Fosse's writing style is characterized by simple, minimal, searing dialogue similar to Samuel Beckett and Harold Pinter. His themes explore the absurdity, futility, and power of the human condition, everyday confusions and irresolutions, and the difficulty of forming connections through conversation. While Fosse has been celebrated in Europe for a long time, he is not as popular in English-speaking countries like the UK and US due to difficulties in relating to his themes and connecting with his plays. However, his popularity has been increasing in these geographies in recent years.

item.title: How Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj killed Afzal Khan with his ‘Wagh Nakh’
item.description: The Cultural Affairs Minister of Maharashtra, Sudhir Mungantiwar, has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Victoria and Albert Museum in London to bring back Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj's wagh nakh to the state. The wagh nakh is a medieval claw-like dagger that was used across the Indian subcontinent. It will be displayed in museums across Maharashtra for a period of three years. The most famous use of the wagh nakh comes from the story of Afzal Khan's killing by Shivaji. The weapon was brought to Britain by James Grant Duff, an East India Company officer, and it is currently housed in the Victoria and Albert Museum. The return of the wagh nakh is part of a larger trend of former colonies demanding the return of cultural artifacts taken during colonial times.

item.title: Sarakka Central Tribal University approved for Telangana: The figures of Sammakka-Sarakka, their significance
item.description: The Union cabinet has approved the establishment of the Sarakka Central Tribal University in Telangana, India. The university, which will be located in Mulugu district, is estimated to cost Rs 889 crore. The university was initially promised by the Central government as part of the Andhra Pradesh Reorganisation Act in 2014, which stated that both Andhra Pradesh and Telangana would receive support to establish a tribal university each. However, the Telangana tribal university faced challenges due to delays in land allocation. Prime Minister Narendra Modi recently announced that the university would be named after Sammakka-Sarakka, a revered mother-daughter duo among the local tribal community. The duo played a significant role in a 13th-century battle against local rulers who imposed taxes on the Koya people. The region holds a biennial festival called Sammakka Saralamma Jatara, which is considered one of the largest gatherings of tribal people in the world. The festival attracts millions of devotees from various tribal and non-tribal communities across India. The Ministry of Tribal Affairs and the state government of Telangana provide financial support for the festival, and the Ministry of Tourism has sanctioned funds for the development of a tribal circuit in the area.

item.title: Why Punjab wants to ban the cultivation of PUSA-44 paddy variety
item.description: The Punjab Chief Minister, Bhagwant Singh Mann, has announced that the state will ban the cultivation of the pusa-44 paddy variety from next year. This variety was widely grown in Punjab and covered 70 to 80 percent of the state's total area under paddy cultivation. Farmers were satisfied with its high yield, but the agriculture department and Punjab Agricultural University discouraged its cultivation due to declining groundwater levels. The government aims to conserve one month of irrigation water by banning the variety, as well as address issues such as stubble burning and air pollution. Pusa-44 has an extended maturity period, leading to a narrow window for stubble disposal between paddy harvesting and wheat sowing. The variety is grown extensively in several districts of Punjab, where stubble-burning incidents are high. The ban is expected to have an impact on farmers' income, as pusa-44 yields more than other varieties.

item.title: Delhi HC passes ‘dynamic injunction’ against illegal ICC World Cup broadcast: What this means, what was the case
item.description: The Delhi High Court has issued a "dynamic injunction" to prevent nine websites from illegally broadcasting the ICC Men's Cricket World Cup 2023 matches. The court granted this injunction to protect the revenues of Star India, the official broadcaster of the World Cup, as rogue websites that engage in piracy are likely to illegally broadcast the matches. Dynamic injunctions are granted before copyrighted works are publicly released or created to prevent irreparable loss due to online piracy. The Delhi High Court has previously passed similar injunctions to protect copyrighted works, including films and series. Star India cited previous cases and its exclusive rights acquired from the ICC to seek the injunction. The court's ruling falls under Section 37 of the 1957 Copyright Act, which grants broadcasting organizations special rights and specifies actions that constitute infringement. Exceptions to copyright infringement are included under Section 39 if the reproduction can be considered fair dealing.

item.title: Glacial lake outburst flood kills 14 in Sikkim, 102 people missing: What is GLOF, and why does it happen?
item.description: Fourteen people have been killed and 102 are missing in Sikkim, India, after the South Lhonak Lake burst due to heavy rains. The release of water caused flooding in downstream areas, including four districts. Glacial lakes like South Lhonak Lake are dangerous because they are mostly dammed by unstable ice or sediment, and if the boundary breaks, it can cause flooding. Glacial lake outburst floods (GLOF) can be triggered by earthquakes, heavy rains, or ice avalanches. Rising global temperatures have led to the rapid melting of glaciers in Sikkim Himalayan, resulting in the expansion of glacial lakes. There are currently over 300 glacial lakes in Sikkim Himalayan, with 10 identified as vulnerable to outburst floods. South Lhonak Lake has been under observation for years due to its significant increase in size. In 2016, authorities syphoned off water from the lake to mitigate the risk of a GLOF.

item.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry for 2023: What exactly have the three scientists been honoured for?
item.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry for 2023 has been awarded to Moungi Bawendi, Louis Brus, and Alexei Ekimov for their discovery and synthesis of quantum dots. Quantum dots are small particles of nanotechnology that have various applications, including in televisions, LED lamps, and guiding surgeons during tumor removal. While scientists had theorized about the existence of these particles, the three laureates were able to create high-quality quantum dots that could be practically used. Ekimov was the first to make notable discoveries but his research was not accessible beyond the Iron Curtain. Ekimov and Brus independently observed how the size of particles affected their absorption of light, leading to the realization that particle size alters characteristics and behavior. Bawendi further improved the creation of quantum dots using different methods. Quantum dots are now utilized in computer and television screens, LED lamps, biochemistry, and medicine.

item.title: Why Punjab is burdened with debt of Rs 3.27 lakh crore
item.description: Punjab Chief Minister Bhagwant Mann has written a letter to Governor Banwarilal Purohit, requesting a five-year moratorium on the state's growing debt. Punjab's debt is estimated to reach Rs 3.27 lakh crore by the end of this fiscal year. The government has already spent a significant amount on debt servicing, with 20% of the annual budget going towards loan repayments. If the situation does not improve, Punjab's debt could exceed Rs 4 lakh crore in two years. The state's debt has multiplied nearly ten times over the past twenty years, largely due to "freebies" provided by the government, such as power subsidies. Economists suggest that a moratorium on debt repayment and a special package from the central government could help revive Punjab's economy and attract private investment. It is crucial for Punjab to change its course promptly to avoid becoming a "debt-trapped" state and to benefit the Indian economy as a whole.

item.title: How Republican leader McCarthy became the first ever US House Speaker to be removed from office
item.description: Kevin McCarthy, the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, was ousted by a group of Republican leaders in a no-confidence vote. This is the first time a House Speaker has lost such a vote. McCarthy had the support of most Republicans but lost eight votes from his own party. The motion to remove him was brought by Matt Gaetz, a far-right Republican representative, who criticized McCarthy for mishandling government spending and budget fights. McCarthy's close relationship with former President Donald Trump and his impeachment inquiry into President Joe Biden also contributed to his ouster. Patrick T McHenry, a Republican representative from North Carolina, has temporarily replaced McCarthy as acting Speaker. The path to electing a new Speaker remains uncertain due to deep polarization within the House and the Republican party.

item.title: Physics Nobel 2023: They made it possible to watch electrons move
item.description: French physicist Pierre Agostini, Hungarian physicist Ferenc Krausz, and French physicist Anne L'Huillier have been awarded the 2023 Nobel Prize in Physics for their work on generating attosecond pulses of light to study electron dynamics in matter. Their breakthrough allows scientists to observe processes at the atomic and subatomic levels that were previously impossible to observe. The development of attosecond pulses has potential applications in various fields, including electronics and medicine. This is the third Nobel Prize in this field in the last three decades, highlighting its significance in scientific research.
